title: McCullough v. McCullough
text:

  THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
  
    
      
        
          Vernon Lee McCullough, Respondent,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
          Tressy Chick McCullough, Appellant.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Richland County
  Â Marion D. Myers, Family Court Judge
  
  Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-367
  Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 6, 2005
  
  REVERSED AND REMANDED
  
  
    
      
        
          William T. Toal, of Columbia, for Appellant.
          Vernon Lee McCullough, of Columbia, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  PER CURIAM: Tressy Chick McCullough (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order denying her request for Vernon Lee McCullough (Father) to pay retroactive child support.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
  FACTS
  Father and Mother married on August 9, 1993, and had one child together in July 1998.Â  Mother and Father separated in January 1998. 
  On October 24, 2002, Father, who was incarcerated, filed for divorce on the statutory ground of living separate and apart for one year.Â  He also requested the trial court reserve the right to award child support until after he was released from prison.Â  In her answer and counterclaim, Mother admitted separation without cohabitation for more than one year and requested a divorce, child support, back child support, custody, and a bar to alimony.Â  
  During the trial, Mother presented a financial declaration that she subsequently modified on the record. Â She testified that she earned approximately $1,450 per month, a forty percent decrease from the $2,416 gross monthly income stated on her financial declaration.Â  She explained her income was reduced when she was placed on short-term disability for injuries sustained in an automobile accident.Â  Fatherâ€™s financial declaration showed his average monthly salary to be $1,982.Â  However, Father testified at trial that he had â€œaverage[d] about â€“ about [$]4,000 a monthâ€ since April 2003.Â  Father also admitted that he had not paid any child support in the past.Â Â Â  
  In its order dated January 7, 2004, the family court:Â  (1) granted the parties a divorce based on the ground of living separate and apart for a period of one year; (2) awarded Mother custody of the partiesâ€™ minor child; (3) ordered Father to pay child support in the amount of $575 per month; (4) ordered Father to pay retroactive child support dating from April 15, 2003, in the amount of $4,000; (5) equitably divided the marital estate; (6) denied alimony to either party; and (7) permitted Mother to resume her maiden name. 
  Subsequently, Father filed a motion for reconsideration in which he claimed the family court erred:Â  (1) in determining child support because he was not released from prison until May 2003; (2) assessing the number of dependents claimed by Mother; and (3) calculating Fatherâ€™s gross monthly income.Â  Following a hearing on the motion, the court affirmed its order with the exception of the award of retroactive child support.Â  Without explanation, the court ordered retroactive child support to be stricken from the original order.Â  Mother appeals the family courtâ€™s decision with respect to retroactive child support.
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  â€œOn appeal from an order of the family court, this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 304, 540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000).Â  However, this does not mean that this court should disregard the findings of the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999).
  DISCUSSION
  Mother claims the trial court erred in striking the award of retroactive child support.[2]Â  We agree.Â  
  We preface our discussion of this issue by noting that Father failed to file a brief.Â  Based on this fact alone, we would be justified in reversing the family courtâ€™s order.Â  See Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR (â€œUpon the failure of respondent to timely file a brief, the appellate court may take such action as it deems proper.â€); Wierszewski v. Tokarick, 308 S.C. 441, 444 n.2, 418 S.E.2d 557, 559 n.2 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding that where respondent failed to file a brief appellate court deemed it proper â€œto reverse on the points presented rather than to search the record for reasons to affirmâ€); see also Smith v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 284 S.C. 469, 471, 327 S.E.2d 348, 349 (1985)(holding, under prior appellate court rules, the supreme court would not â€œgrope in the darkâ€ in order to identify errors).Â  Despite Fatherâ€™s failure to adhere to the appellate court rules, we deem it proper to address the merits of Motherâ€™s appeal.
  Both parents have an obligation to support their children.Â  Wint v. Wint, 310 S.C. 48, 50, 425 S.E.2d 48, 49 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  The entitlement to retroactive child support depends upon the facts and circumstances of each case.Â  Sutton v. Sutton, 291 S.C. 401, 408, 353 S.E.2d 884, 888 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  â€œThe issue of retroactive support is to be resolved in accordance with the evidence presented.â€Â  Major v. Major, 277 S.C. 318, 321, 286 S.E.2d 666, 668 (1982).Â  
  The decision to award retroactive child support rests in the sound discretion of the family court.Â  Kelly v. Kelly, 310 S.C. 299, 302, 423 S.E.2d 153, 155 (Ct. App. 1992); see Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 197, 371 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1988) (stating â€œ[t]he question of the award of child support is largely within the discretion of the trial judge whose decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shownâ€).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon the findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).
  Section 20-7-852(A) of the South Carolina Code establishes a â€œpresumption that the amount of the award which would result from the application of the guidelines . . . is the correct amount of child support to be awarded.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-852(A) (Supp. 2004).Â  However, â€œ[a] different amount may be awarded upon a showing that application of the guidelines in a particular case would be unjust or inappropriate.â€Â  Id.
  Under the specific facts of this case, we find the family court erred in eliminating Fatherâ€™s obligation to pay Mother retroactive child support.Â  Initially, we note the court failed to give an explanation for striking Motherâ€™s award of retroactive alimony.Â  In view of the absence of factual findings, we can discern no reason for this complete reversal of the award.Â  Although Father moved for the court to reconsider the amount of the retroactive child support and the amount of the monthly child support, he never challenged Motherâ€™s entitlement to an award of retroactive child support.Â  In fact, Motherâ€™s counsel, not Father, drew the courtâ€™s attention to Fatherâ€™s issue regarding the amount of the award of retroactive child support.Â  Furthermore, at the initial hearing Mother specifically requested retroactive child support.Â  Father also testified that he began working in April 2003 and had not paid any child support.
  Because there is no evidence to support the family courtâ€™s decision to strike the award of retroactive child support, we find the ruling constituted an abuse of discretion.Â  Accordingly, we remand for the court to reconsider this issue and provide specific findings of fact.Â  On remand, if retroactive child support is warranted, the court should recalculate the amount based on Fatherâ€™s actual monthly income and payment for health insurance, Motherâ€™s monthly income, and the correct number of dependents in accordance with the child support guidelines.[3]Â  
  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is
  REVERSED AND REMANDED.
  HEARN, C.J., BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.


  [1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.


  [2]Â Â  Because both issues raised by Mother concern the award of retroactive child support, we have consolidated them in the interest of brevity and clarity.


  [3]Â  Based on our review of the record, it appears the $4,000 award of retroactive child support was calculated using an amount of monthly child support that significantly deviated from the child support guidelines.Â  Specifically, the partiesâ€™ only mutual child should have been considered for the award of support.Â  Additionally, the record indicates that Fatherâ€™s monthly salary is substantially less than the $4,000 amount apparently relied upon by the family court.Â  In light of these discrepancies, the family court may wish to reconsider the amount of monthly child support as well as the amount of retroactive child support.Â  If the court determines that the support award should deviate from the guidelines, it should make specific findings of fact outlining the basis for the award.Â  See Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 452, 539 S.E.2d 712, 716 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œDeviation from the Guidelines should be the exception rather than the rule.Â  When the court orders a child support award that varies significantly from the amount resulting from the application of the Guidelines, the court shall make specific, written findings of those facts upon which it bases its conclusion supporting the award.â€) (citations omitted).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Gary Smith, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Thermo Information Solutions Inc. and Traveler's Indemnity Company of Illinois, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â DanielÂ  F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-368
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 6, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Byron Putnam Roberts, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Malcolm M. Crosland, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the single commissioner found that Gary Smith suffered a brain injury as a result of a work-related accident and awarded total disability benefits.Â  The full commission and the circuit court affirmed.Â  Thermo Information Solutions, Inc. (Employer) challenges the finding that Smith suffered a brain injury, as well as the award of total disability benefits.Â  Employer also challenges the single commissionerâ€™s weekly wage finding and raises a statute of limitations defense.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR, and the following authorities: 
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Brain Injury and Total Disability 
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) and (e) (Supp. 2004) (explaining that a reviewing court may reverse or modify an agency decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or modify an agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-10 (Supp. 2004) (â€œ[A]ny person determined to be totally and permanently disabled who as a result of a compensable injury . . . has suffered physical brain damage . . . shall receive the benefits for life.â€); Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œOn appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports its findings.â€); Howell v. Pacific Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987) (â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify its action.â€); Linen v. Ruscon Constr. Co., 286 S.C. 67, 70, 332 S.E.2d 211, 212 (1985) (holding that when a claimantâ€™s medical expert is properly qualified, the testimony of the claimant and the expert can satisfy the substantial evidence requirement); Pearson v. JPS Converter & Indus. Corp., 327 S.C. 393, 400, 489 S.E.2d 219, 222 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œ[S]ection 42-9-10 does not require the total and permanent disability to be solely the result of physical brain damageâ€”the statute only requires that a claimant be totally and permanently disabled and suffer physical brain damage as a result of the injury.â€); McCollum v. Singer Co., 300 S.C. 103, 107, 386 S.E.2d 471, 474 (Ct. App. 1989) (explaining that under section 42-9-10, â€œtotal disability does not require complete, abject helplessnessâ€).Â Â Â  
II.Â Â Â Â  Average Weekly Wage Finding
Suddeth v. Knight, 280 S.C. 540, 544, 314 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œStipulations will not be so construed as to give the effect of an admission of fact obviously intended to be controverted or the waiver of a right not plainly intended to be relinquished.â€); 83 C.J.S. Stipulations Â§ 47 (2004) (explaining that stipulations will not be given a forced construction, and a construction should be adopted that is fair and will render it reasonable to both parties, and which will aid in a fair trial on the merits).
III.Â Â Â  Statute of Limitations
Hamilton v. Bob Bennett Ford, 336 S.C. 72, 77, 518 S.E.2d 599, 601 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating that once workersâ€™ compensation forms are filed providing all the information that could reasonably be required to be in a claim, the claim is established and the statute of limitations is satisfied).Â Â  

AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        David H. Nelson, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kathryn Dale Nelson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Richard W. Chewning, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-369
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland, NC, and Sheila McNair Robinson, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a domestic action for modification of alimony consolidated with an appeal from the divorce decree.Â  Kathryn Dale Nelson (Wife) appealed the divorce decree ordering David H. Nelson (Husband) to pay her alimony in the amount of $500 per month.Â  Her appeal was held in abeyance while Husband sought a reduction in alimony based on changed circumstances.Â  The family court found a substantial change in circumstances and reduced the amount of alimony from $500 per month to $250 per month.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in 1980.Â  At the time of the divorce, Husband was 56 years of age and Wife was 54.Â  Although Wife is a seven-year cancer survivor and Husband suffers high blood pressure, both parties are in reasonably good health.Â  Each party received a high school diploma.Â  The partiesâ€™ three children have reached the age of majority.Â  Wife did not work outside the home during the marriage except for a short period in the fall of 2000.Â  However, she contributed to the marriage by performing household services such as cleaning, cooking, and caring for the children.Â  
Husband worked for BellSouth as a telephone specialist for over 30 years.Â  After the parties separated, Wife took a job as an office clerk with the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division (SLED).Â  The coupleâ€™s standard of living during the marriage was impacted by excessive consumer debt.Â  At the time of the divorce hearing, they owed nearly $37,000â€”more than the equity in the marital home.Â  
Husband earned a gross monthly income of $4,741.66 and a net monthly income of $3,072.42.Â  Wife earned a gross monthly income of $1,484.90 and a net monthly income of $1,053.70.Â  Neither party anticipated an increase in income.Â  
In August of 2000, the family court issued a temporary order setting alimony at $500 per month.Â  Husband was ordered to contribute $750 toward Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  By order filed May 17, 2001, the family court increased the alimony to $1,000 per month, as the marital home was sold and Husband was no longer required to make the mortgage payments.Â  
In the final order of divorce, the family court found both parties claimed expenses in excess of their income.Â  The court found Husbandâ€™s financial declaration truthful and honest.Â  The court found Wife inflated her expenses.Â  From a net monthly income of $1,053.70, she claimed expenses totaling $3,318.48, including $266 per month for dental work she had not yet incurred, $300 per month for clothing, $300 per month for incidentals, and $275 per month for entertainment.Â  
Husband had no non-marital assets.Â  The Wife had a one-third interest in two parcels of family real estate in Florence:Â  a home listed for sale for $85,900 at the time of the hearing, and a 120-acre farm, both of which were non-marital assets.Â  The assets divided in equitable distribution consisted primarily of the proceeds from the sale of the marital home and Husbandâ€™s retirement account.Â  The court allocated 60% of the estate to Husband because he had been the sole financial contributor to the marriage.Â  Each party retained a vehicle.Â  The court awarded Wife alimony as follows:Â  $150 per month beginning December 1, 2001, $200 per month beginning December 1, 2002, and $250 per month beginning December 1, 2003.Â  
Wife filed a motion for reconsideration.Â  The family court refused her request for $1,000 per month but increased the alimony to $500 per month.Â  Wife appealed this order.Â  With the permission of this court, the appeal was held in abeyance pending Husbandâ€™s retirement.Â  Husband then filed an action for modification of alimony.Â  Wife answered and counterclaimed for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
After a hearing, the family court found Husband had experienced a substantial and material change in circumstances.Â  Husband took voluntary retirement from BellSouth with a lump sum payment of one and a half times his annual salary.Â  The entire sum was paid to Wife to satisfy the equitable distribution ordered in the divorce decree.Â  
Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income fell to $1,496.36 and his net monthly income to $1,014.65.Â  Additionally, Husbandâ€™s property, excluding retirement, decreased from $42,846.87 to $4,772.67.Â  Husband was also required to pay for his insurance coverage and was experiencing new medical problems, including diabetes.Â  
In contrast, the family court found Wifeâ€™s financial situation had improved.Â  She had been promoted to a full-time position at SLED and had received an increase in pay.Â  Her gross monthly income increased to $1,607 and her net monthly income to $1,243, excluding the alimony.Â  Additionally, her monthly expenses decreased almost $2,000, from $3,318.48 to $1,352.Â  She had purchased a new house in a residential community with a fenced-in yard and a security system.Â  Moreover, Wifeâ€™s assets had increased, including $43,000 in a savings account.Â  She retained her one-third interest in the 120-acre farm in Florence and the house, which was then listed for sale for $59,500.Â  She also had an undisclosed sum in her SLED retirement account.Â  
The family court found that Husband met his burden of showing a substantial and material change of circumstances and ordered the alimony reduced to $250 per month.Â  Wife also appeals this order. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, this court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 335, 569 S.E.2d 393, 397 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court, however.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  â€œNeither are we required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Roberson v. Roberson, 359 S.C. 384, 388, 597 S.E.2d 840, 842 (Ct. App. 2004) (citation omitted).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

A.Â  Alimony
Wife argues error in the divorce decree setting alimony at $500, down from the $1,000 set in the temporary order.Â  Wife also appeals the modification order, setting alimony at $250 based on Husbandâ€™s retirement.Â  We find no error.
The amount of alimony varied throughout the course of the litigation.Â  The family court temporarily ordered alimony of $500 per month and increased it to $1,000 per month after the marital home was sold.Â  After the hearing, the family court modified it to $150 per month beginning on December 1, 2001, $200 per month beginning on December 1, 2002, and $250 per month beginning on December 1, 2003.Â  However, in the order on Wifeâ€™s motion to alter or amend, the family court increased alimony to $500 per month.Â  Following Husbandâ€™s action for modification, the family court reduced it to $250 per month.Â  
1.Â  The Divorce Decree
Wife first argues that the family court erred in setting the alimony amount at $500 per month following the divorce, a reduction from $1,000 per month in the temporary order.Â  We disagree. 
â€œAn award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 183-84, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the judge is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Roberson, 359 S.C. at 390, 597 S.E.2d at 843. 
â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support that is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 599, 506 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œThe purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse in the position he or she enjoyed during the marriage.â€Â  Deidun v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 63, 606 S.E.2d 489, 498 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, alimony should not serve as a disincentive for a spouse to improve his employment potential or to dissuade him from providing for his own support.Â  Id. 
A court must consider the following factors in making an alimony award:Â  (1) the duration of the marriage; (2) the physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) the educational background of the parties; (4) the employment history and earning potential of both parties; (5) their standard of living during the marriage; (6) their current and reasonably anticipated earnings; (7) their current and reasonably anticipated expenses; (8) the marital and non-marital properties of the parties; (9) custody of the children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations of either party; and (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2004). 
The family court carefully considered each of the statutory factors in the amended divorce decree and then reconsidered the amount of alimony in the final order.Â  In particular, the family court found Husband lacked the ability to pay $1,000 per month based on his financial declarations.Â  The family court observed that a large alimony amount would unduly penalize Husband.Â  See Beasley v. Beasley, 264 S.C. 611, 612, 216 S.E.2d 535, 535-36 (1975) (stating that alimony should not penalize one party and reward the other).Â  
Moreover, the family court questioned the veracity of the Wifeâ€™s expenses in her financial declaration.Â  The court found her expenditures of $300 per month for clothing, $300 per month for incidentals, and $275 per month for entertainment to be excessive.Â  Additionally, the family court found her reported estimate of future monthly expenditures of $266 per month for dental work speculative.Â  The court further observed that Wifeâ€™s financial declaration failed to include her one-third interest in the Florence family properties.Â  The family court found the properties were capable of generating additional income for Wife.Â  
We find no error in the family courtâ€™s decision.Â  The family court judge was in a better position to evaluate the credibility and assign comparative weight to the testimony of the witnesses.Â  There was ample support for the award of $500 per month.
2.Â  Husbandâ€™s Modification Action
Wife next challenges the reduction of the alimony to $250 per month in Husbandâ€™s action for modification based on changed circumstances.Â  Wife contends Husbandâ€™s retirement should not be considered a change of circumstances because it was within the contemplation of the parties at the time of the divorce decree.Â  We disagree.
â€œChanged conditions may warrant a modification or termination of alimony.â€Â  Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œTo justify modification, the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material.â€Â  Pendergast v. Pendergast, 354 S.C. 32, 38, 579 S.E.2d 530, 533 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Voluntary changes in employment that impact a spouseâ€™s ability to pay alimony will be closely scrutinized, and the family court may impute income in such situations.Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 488, 477 S.E.2d 727, 731 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
Generally, changes within the contemplation of the parties at the time of the divorce decree do not provide grounds for modification of alimony.Â  Calvert v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 139, 336 S.E.2d 884, 889 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  However, events that are anticipated but considered distant at the time the decree is entered may qualify as changed circumstances permitting modification in alimony.Â  Sharps v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 77, 535 S.E.2d 913, 916 (2000).Â  In Sharps, the court explained as follows:Â  â€œAs a general rule, a court hearing an application for a change in alimony should look not only to see if the substantial change was contemplated by the parties, but most importantly whether the amount of alimony in the original decree reflects the expectation of that future occurrence.â€Â  Id. at 78, 535 S.E.2d at 917.Â  
The family court noted in the divorce decree that Husband was â€œapproaching retirement age.â€Â  However, Husband testified at the hearing that he planned to work at least six more years before retiring.Â  Although Husbandâ€™s retirement was voluntary, Husband retired because his employer announced an anticipated layoff of 4,000 to 5,000 managers and offered early retirement packages.Â  Husband testified that the retirement package, a lump sum payment of one and a half times his annual salary, was the best he had seen while employed at BellSouth.Â  
Moreover, the change in financial condition of the parties was significant.Â  As a result of retirement, Husbandâ€™s monthly income was significantly reduced.Â  Meanwhile, Wifeâ€™s financial condition had substantially improved.Â  Her monthly income increased and her expenses decreased.Â  We find no error in the family courtâ€™s finding of changed circumstances.
B.Â  Equitable Distribution
Wife next contends the family court should have ordered an equal division of the marital estate.Â  We disagree. 
Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) sets forth the equitable apportionment factors a court must consider and vests the family court with discretion to weigh the evidence bearing on each factor.Â  â€œOn review, this Court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment.Â  If the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that this Court might have weighed specific factors differently than the trial judge.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988) (internal citation omitted).Â  
Wife did not work outside the home at all during the marriage, except for a two or three-month period when she had a part-time job.Â  In similar cases, the appellate courts of this state have upheld a similar split.Â  In Pool v. Pool, the wife made approximately twenty percent of the financial contributions to the marriage in addition to her contributions as a homemaker.Â  321 S.C. 84, 87, 467 S.E.2d 753, 755 (Ct. App. 1996), modified on other grounds, 329 S.C. 324, 494 S.E.2d 820 (1998).Â  The court found no abuse of discretion in a 60/40 split.Â  Id. at 88, 467 S.E.2d at 756.Â  See also Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 24, 553 S.E.2d 251, 255 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding a 65/35 property split fair and equitable); Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 358, 396 S.E.2d 124, 127 (Ct. App. 1990) (upholding a 70/30 property split).Â  
The family court in this case recited that it considered all of the statutory factors regarding equitable apportionment found in section 20-7-472.Â  Although Wife made significant indirect contributions to the marriage, Husband was the sole financial contributor.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â  
C.Â  Factual Finding Regarding Wifeâ€™s Inherited Property
Wife next contends the family court erred in finding her interest in the Florence properties afforded her â€œa sufficient financial resource from which she is able to generate additional funds.â€Â  We disagree. 
South Carolina law requires a court to consider, inter alia, the opportunity of each spouse for future acquisition of capital assets, and the non-marital property of each spouse.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(4) & (7) (Supp. 2004).Â  When determining the amount of alimony, a court must consider marital and non-marital properties of the parties, and any other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(8) & (13) (Supp. 2004). 
Wife first points out that although the house was listed for $85,900 at the time of the hearing, the price was subsequently reduced to $59,500 and no offers had been received due to extensive termite damage.Â  Despite the need for repairs to one of the properties, the potential for Wife to generate income or funds from both properties continues to exist.Â  We find no error.
D.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife finally argues the family court erred in requiring the parties to pay their own attorney fees.Â  We affirm.Â  
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Â See Bowen v. Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  
The family court found that both parties had achieved beneficial results and neither party was at fault in the breakup of the marriage.Â  We find no error.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.

ANDERSON, STILWELL, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
 THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals 

  
    
      
        Kenneth A. Marshall, Vol-World, LLC, and Springerland, Inc., Respondents, 
      
    
  


  
    
v.

  
    
      
        John W. Pence, Jerry B. Massey, Planets Edge, Inc., Joseph Hickman and Annie Hickman, Defendants,
        Of whom John W. Pence, Jerry B. Massey, and Planets Edge, Inc. are the, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-370
  Heard April 5, 2005 â€“ Filed June 7, 2005


  REVERSED



  
    
      
        William B. Jung, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.
        Saul Gliserman and O. Grady Query, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  This is an appeal from a trial courtâ€™s grant of a preliminary injunction.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
 Joseph and Annie Hickman own 32A Centre Street in Folly Beach, South Carolina.Â  From 1997 until 2003, the Hickmans leased the property to Ken (â€œMarshallâ€) and Mary Marshall through the Marshallsâ€™ corporation, Springerland, Inc., for use as a restaurant and bar named Planet Follywood.Â  Upon the Marshallâ€™s petition for divorce, the family court issued a temporary order, awarding Mary Marshall sole control over the operations of Planet Follywood.
In October 2003, John Pence, a Planet Follywood patron, and Marshall discussed the potential of forming a partnership or association to run Planet Follywood.Â  Pence introduced Marshall to Rick Neighbors as a potential third partner because Neighbors â€œhad started, managed and sold a number of successful businesses.â€Â  Marshallâ€™s primary concern was having a name other than his listed as the owner of the business because he had unpaid tax liens owed to the IRS.Â  However, the discussions ended because Marshall did not want Neighbors as a partner.Â  After Marshall approached Pence a second time in November 2003 about forming a business relationship, Pence suggested his son-in-law Jerry Massey, manager of a local restaurant franchise, as the third partner.Â  Marshall, Pence, and Massey met at Penceâ€™s home later that month to discuss the organization of the business and inspect Springerlandâ€™s financial books.Â  Because of Marshallâ€™s IRS difficulties, Massey agreed to put all necessary permits and licenses in his name, including the lease on the 32A Centre Street property.Â  Massey also agreed to handle the day-to-day operations of the restaurant and bar because Marshall expressed a desire to continue his job in construction; however, Marshall wanted a portion of the monthly proceeds from the operation of the new business. 
At trial, Marshall testified he simply asked Pence to help him meet the past due rental amounts so he could take over the restaurant once his divorce proceedings were final.Â  He stated he never intended to form a partnership with Pence or Massey, but he admits he discussed a business association with them at some point.Â Â Â Â  
The Hickmans notified Marshall in early December that Mary Marshall was behind on her rent payments.[1]Â  They began formal eviction proceedings against Springerland on December 22, 2003, though the â€œproceedings [were] never concluded and . . . therefore [eventually] deemed by [the] court to be null and void.â€ Â In addition, the IRS ordered Planet Follywood to close at the end of December 2003 because of Springerlandâ€™s unpaid tax liens.Â  Subsequently, Mary Marshall threw a going out of business and customer appreciation party on December 25, 2003.Â  
On December 16, 2003, Massey, Pence, and Marshall met with the Hickmans to discuss the new lease on the property.Â  At that meeting, Massey paid $3,200 to the Hickmans for December 2003 and January 2004 rent on the property.Â  Also during the meeting, Joseph Hickman signed a document, witnessed by Annie Hickman and Massey and in the presence of Marshall and Pence, attesting to his receipt of rent for the months of â€œDec. 03 and January 04 from the new tenants of Planet Follywood 32 Center St Folly Beach SC 29439.Â  The new lease will be prepared in ap[p]rox two weeks by atty Ben Peeples.Â  New tenants are [sic] Jerry Massey.â€Â  Massey testified that Marshall was present for the meeting, the payment of the rent, and the signing of the temporary lease agreement from the Hickmans to Massey; however, Marshall testified that he was not at the meeting.Â  Shortly thereafter, Massey formed a corporation named Planets Edge, Inc. for purpose of operating the new business.Â  Planets Edge signed a one-year lease with the Hickmanâ€™s for 32A Centre Street that contained an option to renew until December 2009. 
While Massey, Pence, their respective spouses, and occasionally Marshall prepared the restaurant for opening, Marshallâ€™s divorce became final.Â  As a result of the settlement, on January 15, 2004, Mary Marshall paid Marshall $50,000, satisfied the IRS tax lien against Springerland, and surrendered her interest in Springerland to Marshall.[2]Â  Massey testified that Marshall contacted Pence on January 17, 2004 and scheduled a meeting at the property for the following day, where he informed Massey that he did not â€œthink this partnership [was] going to workâ€ because Massey was â€œtoo corporateâ€ for a family business like Planet Follywood.Â  Marshall stated to both Massey and Pence that he would not do business with either of them in the future.Â  Unbeknownst to Pence and Massey until that day, Marshall had applied for liquor licenses and other permits on January 15 and 16, 2004 in his name and the name of his new corporation, Vol-World, LLC, thereby preventing Appellants from obtaining permits for the same address in their corporate name.
To protect their investment, Massey and Pence contacted legal counsel, and after notifying the Hickmans, changed the locks on the 32A Centre Street building.Â  Respondents[3] instituted a breach of contract action against the Hickmans.Â  Respondents also brought an action for intentional interference with contractual relations, conversion, trespass, and forcible entry and detainer against Appellants.Â  In their amended complaint, Respondents withdrew the breach of contract claim against the Hickmans and added a request for specific performance of the 1997 lease between Springerland and Hickman.Â  They also requested injunctive relief awarding them possession of 32A Centre Street and the return of any personal property belonging to Springerland left inside the premises.Â Â  
From January 2003 until the trial court ordered the preliminary injunction on February 27, 2004, Appellants remained in possession of the 32A Centre Street premises and were current on all rent due for the premises.Â  Marshall also was current on all rent due for the premises.Â  Following the hearing on February 27, 2004, the trial court ordered Appellants to vacate the premises and â€œimmediately grant access to the said premises toâ€ Respondents, once Respondents posted a $3,200 attachment bond.Â  The trial court held the following:

  [T]here was [sic] discussions to lead up to the formation of a partnership, but a partnership was never formed.Â  Secondly, as far as the competing leases are concerned, I think that the first lease is still valid and it is enforced [sic] and therefore Iâ€™ll grant the injunction, the temporary injunction, turning the property over to the plaintiff.

This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants claim the trial court erred in awarding a preliminary injunction to Respondents because Appellants were in actual possession under â€œcolor of right.â€Â  We agree. 
Actions for injunctive relief are equitable.Â  Doe v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 347 S.C. 642, 645, 557 S.E.2d 670, 672 (2001).Â  In equitable actions, we may review the record and make findings of fact in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Id.Â  â€œPursuant to the â€˜main purpose rule,â€™ in actions praying for both money damages and equitable relief, â€˜characterization of the action as equitable or legal depends on the plaintiffâ€™s â€˜main purposeâ€™ in bringing the action.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Floyd v. Floyd, 306 S.C. 376, 380, 412 S.E.2d 397, 399 (1991)).Â  Marshallâ€™s main purpose in instituting this action was to restore the status quo.Â  Thus, the â€œmain purposeâ€ of Marshallâ€™s action was equitable in nature.Â  However, â€œ[t]he granting of temporary injunctive relief is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  City of Columbia v. Pic-A-Flick Video, Inc., 340 S.C. 278, 282, 531 S.E.2d 518, 520 (2000).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Id. at 282, 531 S.E.2d at 521.Â  
Ordinarily the purpose of a temporary injunction is merely to preserve the existing status during the litigation, and as a general rule, subject to some exceptions, it will not be allowed to have the effect of transferring the possession of property from a litigant in possession to another who claims the right to possession.Â  Atlantic Coast Lumber Corp. v. E.P. Burton Lumber Co., 89 S.C. 143, 145, 71 S.E. 820, 820 (1911).Â  â€œIn case of property rights the purpose is to preserve the status quo pending litigation.â€Â  County Council of Charleston v. Felkel, 244 S.C. 480, 484, 137 S.E.2d 577, 578 (1964).Â  If â€œthe right of possession is in dispute between two parties, one of whom is in actual possession under a claim or color of right, injunction will not, as a rule, lie to transfer possession to the other party.â€Â  43A C.J.S. Injunctions Â§ 127 (2004) (emphasis added). 
Appellants were in actual possession of the property prior to February 27, 2004 when the temporary injunction was issued.Â  Although there was some debate as to Marshallâ€™s intent to enter into a partnership and which of the partiesâ€™ leases was primary, there was some evidence that Appellants were in possession of 32A Centre Street by â€œcolor of right.â€Â  See 43A C.J.S. Injunctions Â§ 127 (2004).Â  Marshall requested that Pence help him financially to get the business operating again and possibly entered into an oral partnership agreement with Pence and Massey.Â  Also, Mary Marshall failed to make rent payments on the lease and the Hickmans executed eviction proceedings.Â  Further, Joseph Hickman handwrote a note to Massey, in the presence of his wife, Pence, and arguably Marshall to the effect that Massey was the â€œNew Tenantâ€ of 32A Centre Street and had paid rent for December 2003 and January 2004.Â  The Hickmans and Planet Edge entered into a lease agreement on January 16, 2004.Â  This evidence, whether disputed or not, prevents the trial court from transferring possession, thereby preserving the status quo.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Furthermore, as the Appellants argue, the issue of title is a legal issue to be tried by a jury.Â  â€œWhile it is true a suit for injunction invokes the equitable jurisdiction of the court, yet if the defendant claims paramount title to the land in dispute and the subject of the equitable proceeding, which title if confirmed in the defendant would defeat the equitable remedy of injunction, then the issue of title should be tried first, and it is a legal issue to be tried by a jury.â€Â  Santee River Hardwood Co. v. Hyman, 44 F.Supp. 857, 859-60 (1942).Â  Thus, the trial court erred in granting a temporary injunction based on its determination that the Springerland lease â€œwill be determined to have priority over the subsequent lease on the premises.â€ 
REVERSED.
BEATTY, J., concurs.
ANDERSON, J., concurs in result only in a separate opinion. 
ANDERSON, J. (concurring in result only):Â  I disagree with the analysis and explication in regard to the issuance and propriety of a temporary (preliminary) injunction.Â  It is necessary and essential to academically review the law extant on the efficacy of temporary injunctions.
TEMPORARY (PRELIMINARY) INJUNCTIONS
An action for an injunction is equitable.Â  Blanks v. Rawson, 296 S.C. 110, 370 S.E.2dÂ  890 (Ct. App. 1988); accord Richland County v. Kaiser, 351 S.C. 89, 567 S.E.2d 260 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  An injunction is not granted as a matter of legal right, but is granted when a review of all of the evidence establishes that it is necessary to prevent irreparable harm.Â  Metts v. Wenberg, 158 S.C. 411, 155 S.E. 734 (1930); Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 167 S.E.2d 313 (1969); see also Shapemasters Golf Course Builders, Inc. v. Shapemasters, Inc., 360 S.C. 473, 602 S.E.2d 83 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding appellant failed to show irreparable harm).Â  Injunctive relief is a drastic remedy which should be used cautiously.Â  Sprouse v. Winston, 212 S.C. 176, 46 S.E.2d 874 (1948); see Scratch Golf Co. v. Dunes West Residential Golf Properties, Inc., 361 S.C. 117, 603 S.E.2d 905 (2004).Â  â€œThe remedy of injunction is a drastic one and should be cautiously applied only when legal rights are unlawfully invaded or legal duties are willingly or wantonly neglected.â€Â  Seabrook Island Prop. Owner Assâ€™n v. Marshland Trust, Inc., 358 S.C. 655, 666, 596 S.E.2d 380, 385 (Ct. App. 2004) (internal quotation marks omitted) (quoting LeFurgy v. Long Cove Club Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n, Inc., 313 S.C. 555, 558, 443 S.E.2d 577, 578 (Ct. App. 1994)).Â  
South Carolina Code Ann. sections 15-55-10 through â€“100 (1976) formerly governed injunctions in this State.Â  However, upon the advent of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure on July 1, 1985, these code sections were repealed.Â  Rule 65, SCRCP, now governs injunctions.Â  
Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 167 S.E.2d 313 (1969), is the leading South Carolina case on temporary injunctions.Â  There, our supreme court edified: 

  The two essential conditions to the granting of a temporary injunction were thus stated in Childs v. City of Columbia, 87 S.C. 566, 568, 70 S.E. 296, 297, 34 L.R.A.,N.S., 542: â€˜First, the complaint must allege facts which appear to be sufficient to constitute a cause of action for injunction; and, second, on the entire showing from both sides it must appear, in view of all the circumstances, that the injunction is reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights of the plaintiff pending the litigation.â€™


  It is well settled that, in determining whether a temporary injunction should issue, the merits of the case are not to be considered, except in so far as they may enable the court to determine whether a prima facie showing has been made.Â  When a prima facie showing has been made entitling plaintiff to injunctive relief, a temporary injunction will be granted without regard to the ultimate termination of the case on the merits.Â  Alderman & Sons Co. v. Wilson, 69 S.C. 156, 48 S.E. 85.


  Injunctive relief, under the foregoing section, is a matter that rests in the sound discretion of the judge to whom application is made and, as stated in Alston v. Board of Health, 93 S.C. 553, 77 S.E. 727, â€˜while a judge, at chambers, cannot Finally decide anything as to the merits, he can and ought to look into the merits, whether they present issues of law or fact, and Consider them to the extent necessary to enable him to exercise his discretion wisely.â€™


  We have held that a temporary injunction may properly issue to protect rights acquired under an easement.Â  Darlington Oil Company v. Pee Dee Oil & Ice Company, 62 S.C. 196, 40 S.E. 169; Alderman & Sons Co. v. Wilson, supra, 69 S.C. 156, 48 S.E. 85; Marion County Lumber Co. v. Tilghman Lumber Co., 75 S.C. 220, 55 S.E. 337.

Transcontinental, 252 S.C. at 480-81, 167 S.E.2d at 315.
Powell v. Immanuel Baptist Church, 261 S.C. 219, 199 S.E.2d 60 (1973), amplified Transcontinental by inculcating the quintessence of temporary injunctions:     

  It is implicit in the language of the statute, and the authorities agree, that the sole purpose of a temporary injunction is to preserve the status quo, and thus avoid possible irreparable injury to plaintiff, pending the litigation.Â  42 Am.Jur.2d, Injunctions, Sec. 13 (1969); County Council of Charleston v. Felkel, 244 S.C. 480, 137 S.E.2d 577 (1964).

Powell, 261 S.C. at 221, 199 S.E.2d at 61 (emphasis added).Â  This point was reiterated by Justice Nessâ€™s dissent in Universal Life Church, Inc., v. City of North Charleston, 277 S.C. 81, 83, 282 S.E.2d 607, 608 (1981): â€œA temporary injunction is properly issued â€˜to preserve the status quo, and thus avoid possible irreparable injury to plaintiff, pending the litigation.â€™Â  (Emphasis supplied).Â  Powell v. Immanuel Baptist Church, et al., 261 S.C. 219, 221, 199 S.E.2d 60 (1973).â€Â  
In Helsel v. City of North Myrtle Beach, 307 S.C. 29, 413 S.E.2d 824 (1992), the South Carolina Supreme Court elucidated:

  The sole purpose of a temporary injunction is to avoid irreparable injury to a plaintiff pending final adjudication of a case.Â  Powell v. Immanuel Baptist Church, 261 S.C. 219, 221, 199 S.E.2d 60, 61 (1973).Â  When a court is requested to issue a temporary injunction it may consider the merits of a case to the extent necessary to determine whether a temporary injunction is appropriate.Â  Roberts v. Union County Board of School Trustees, 284 S.C. 299, 301, 326 S.E.2d 163, 164 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  Once a prima facie showing has been made entitling the plaintiff to injunctive relief, a temporary injunction will be granted without regard to the ultimate termination of the case on the merits.Â  Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. v. Custom Recording Co., Inc., 258 S.C. 465, 471-72, 189 S.E.2d 305, 308 (1972).Â  A temporary injunction is made without prejudice to the rights of either party pending a hearing on the merits, and when other issues are brought to trial, they are determined without reference to the temporary injunction.Â  Alston v. Limehouse, 60 S.C. 559, 569, 39 S.E.2d 188, 191 (1901).Â  

Helsel, 307 S.C. at 32, 413 S.E.2d at 826.Â  
More recently, our supreme court noted:

  The sole object of a temporary injunction is to preserve the subject of the controversy in its condition at the time of the order until opportunity is offered for full and deliberate trial investigation.Â  Epps v. Bryant, 218 S.C. 359, 62 S.E.2d 832 (1950).Â  Temporary injunctions are interlocutory, tentative, and impermanent and are superseded by the final judgment rendered on the merits.Â  42 AM.JUR.2D Injunctions Â§ 294 (2000).Â  Thus, temporary injunctions â€œremain in force only until, and expire upon, the entry of final judgment and are not enforceable after the final judgment has been entered.â€Â  Id.Â  

Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 569, 549 S.E.2d 591, 597 (2001).
In Zabinski v. Bright Acres Associates, 346 S.C. 580, 553 S.E.2d 110 (2001), the court observed:

  The granting of temporary injunctive relief is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  City of Columbia v. Pic-A-Flick Video, Inc., 340 S.C. 278, 531 S.E.2d 518 (2000).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs where the trial court is controlled by an error of law or where the trial courtâ€™s order is based on factual conclusions without evidentiary support.Â  Id.Â  The sole purpose of a temporary injunction is to preserve the status quo and thus avoid possible irreparable injury to a party pending litigation.Â  Powell v. Immanuel Baptist Church, 261 S.C. 219, 199 S.E.2d 60 (1973). 

Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 601, 553 S.E.2d at 121.Â  
The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, in Safety-Kleen, Inc. (Pinewood) v. Wyche, 274 F.3d 846 (4th Cir. 2001), instructed:

  In evaluating whether to grant a preliminary injunction, a court should consider (1) the likelihood of irreparable harm to the plaintiff if the preliminary injunction is denied; (2) the likelihood of harm to the defendant if the injunction is granted; (3) the likelihood that the plaintiff will succeed on the merits; and (4) the public interest.Â  See Direx Israel, Ltd. V. Breakthrough Med. Corp., 952 F.2d 802, 812 (4th Cir. 1991).Â  The â€œlikelihood of irreparable harm to the plaintiffâ€ is the first factor that a court should consider.Â  See id.Â  A courtâ€™s next step is to balance the likelihood of harm to the plaintiff against the likelihood of harm to the defendant.Â  See Blackwelder Furniture Co. v. Seilig Mfg. Co., 550 F.2d 189, 195 (4th Cir. 1977).Â  If the harm balance â€œtips decidedly in favor of the plaintiff, a preliminary injunction will be granted if the plaintiff has raised questions going to the merits so serious, substantial, difficult and doubtful, as to make them fair ground for litigation and thus for more deliberate investigation.â€Â  Rum Creek Coal Sales, Inc. v. Caperton, 926 F.2d 353, 359 (4th Cir. 1991) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).Â  In other words, the plaintiffâ€™s case must at bottom present a â€œsubstantial question.â€

Safety-Kleen, 274 F.3d at 858-59.
In County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 560 S.E.2d 902 (Ct. App. 2002), this Court propounded:

  A plaintiffâ€™s entitlement to an injunction requires the complaint to allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action for injunction while also showing an injunction must be reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights of the plaintiff pending in the litigation.Â  Transcontâ€™l Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 480-81, 167 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1969).Â  Generally, to obtain an injunction, a party must demonstrate irreparable harm, a likelihood of success on the merits, and an inadequate remedy at law.Â  Roach v. Combined Util. Commâ€™n, 290 S.C. 437, 442, 351 S.E.2d 168, 170 (Ct. App. 1986). 

Simpkins, 348 S.C. at 669, 560 S.E.2d at 904
The court, in FOC Lawshe Limited Partnership v. International Paper Company, 352 S.C. 408, 574 S.E.2d 228 (Ct. App. 2002), stated:

  A plaintiffâ€™s entitlement to an injunction requires the complaint to allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action for an injunction while establishing that an injunction is reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights of the plaintiff during the litigation.Â  Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 480-81, 167 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1969).Â  Generally, to obtain an injunction, a party must demonstrate irreparable harm, a likelihood of success on the merits, and an inadequate remedy at law.Â  Roach v. Combined Util. Commâ€™n, 290 S.C. 437, 442, 351 S.E.2d 168, 170 (Ct. App. 1986).

FOC Lawshe, 352 S.C. at 416, 574 S.E.2d at 232.
Subsequently, Mailsource, LLC v. M.A. Bailey & Associates, 356 S.C. 363, 588 S.E.2d 635 (Ct. App. 2003), provided a conscientious review of the law governing temporary injunctions:

  â€œThe granting of temporary injunctive relief is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  City of Columbia v. Pic-A-Flick Video, Inc., 340 S.C. 278, 282, 531 S.E.2d 518, 520-21 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.â€Â  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).
  To warrant a temporary injunction, the complaint must allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action for injunction and the information offered by both sides must demonstrate the injunction to be reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights of the plaintiff pending in the litigation.Â  Transcon. Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 480-81, 167 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1969).Â  Generally, to obtain an injunction, a party must demonstrate irreparable harm, a likelihood of success on the merits, and an inadequate remedy at law.Â  Roach v. Combined Util. Commâ€™n, 290 S.C. 437, 442, 351 S.E.2d 168, 170 (Ct. App. 1986).
  
    It is well settled that, in determining whether a temporary injunction should issue, the merits of the case are not to be considered, except in so far as they may enable the court to determine whether a prima facie showing has been made.Â  When a prima facie showing has been made entitling plaintiff to injunctive relief, a temporary injunction will be granted without regard to the ultimate termination of the case on the merits. 
  
  Transcon., 252 S.C. at 481, 167 S.E.2d at 315.Â  â€œ[T]he sole purpose of a temporary injunction is to preserve the status quo . . . .â€Â  Powell v. Immanuel Baptist Church, 261 S.C. 219, 221, 199 S.E.2d 60, 61 (1973).Â  â€œ[A] temporary injunction is [used] to preserve the subject of controversy in the condition which it is at the time of the Order until opportunity is offered for full and deliberate investigation and to preserve the existing status during litigation . . . .â€Â  County Council of Charleston v. Felkel, 244 S.C. 480, 483-84, 137 S.E.2d 577, 578 (1964) (citation omitted).Â  â€œA temporary injunction is made without prejudice to the rights of either party pending a hearing on the merits, and when other issues are brought to trial, they are determined without reference to the temporary injunction.â€Â  Helsel v. City of N. Myrtle Beach, 307 S.C. 29, 32, 413 S.E.2d 824, 826 (1992).Â  The court should be guided by general principles of equity:
  
    First, the equities of both sides are to be considered, and each case must be decided on its own particular facts.Â  Second, the court of equity must â€œbalance the equitiesâ€ between the parties in determining what if any relief to give.Â  The equities on both sides must be taken into account. 
  
  Foreman v. Foreman, 280 S.C. 461, 464-65, 313 S.E.2d 312, 314 (Ct. App. 1984) (citation omitted).Â  
  â€œ[A] court can, and should, grant a preliminary injunction in an arbitrable dispute whenever an injunction is necessary to preserve the status quo pending arbitration.â€Â  Teradyne, Inc. v. Mostek Corp., 797 F.2d 43, 47 (1st Cir. 1986).Â  The fact that a court orders arbitration of a dispute does not â€œabsolve [it] of its obligation to consider the merits of a requested preliminary injunction.â€Â  Roso-Lino Bev. Distribs., Inc. v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of New York, 749 F.2d 124, 125 (2d Cir. 1984).
   . . . . 
  An injunction is an equitable remedy; as such, it is available only where no remedy at law exists or where the legal remedy would fail to make the party whole.Â  
  
    The general rule is that an injunction should be granted only where some irreparable injury is threatened for which there is no adequate remedy at law.Â  Whether a wrong is irreparable in the sense that equity may intervene, and whether there is an adequate remedy at law for a wrong, are questions that are not decided by narrow and artificial rules.
  
  Cartee v. Lesley, 286 S.C. 249, 256, 333 S.E.2d 341, 345 (Ct. App. 1985) (citation omitted), cert. granted in part on other ground and decision affâ€™d, 290 S.C. 333, 350 S.E.2d 388 (1986); see also Knohl v. Duke Power Co., 260 S.C. 374, 376, 196 S.E.2d 115, 116 (1973) (holding that a â€œcomplaint fails to state a cause of action for injunctive relief unless facts are alleged which show that the plaintiff has no adequate and complete remedy at lawâ€).

Mailsource, 356 S.C. at 367-70, 588 S.E.2d 637-39.
CONCLUSION
The factual and legal basis for the issuance of a temporary injunction did NOT exist in the case sub judice.Â  The evidentiary record demonstrates with clarity that the circuit judge improperly issued a temporary injunction.

[1] The lease between Springerland and the Hickmans included a provision for the event of default:
CANCELLATION OF LEASE BY LESSOR â€“ If Lessee defaults under the payment terms of or for any other violation of this Lease, Lessor shall have the right to demand immediate possession of the premises.Â  If any such default shall occur, Lessor after proper notice of Ten (10) days to Lessee, shall have the right to change the locks to all entries and exits to the premises but shall allow Lessee to remove all personal belongings not under Lease from Lessor.
[2] Interestingly, in their financial declarations before the court, neither Marshall nor Mary Marshall listed Planet Follywood or Springerland as an asset or valuation for configuration of their net worth.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
[3] Respondents consist of Ken Marshall, Vol-World, and Springerland.Â  The Appellants are Pence, Massey, and Planets Edge.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(1), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Larry Cantrell,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Beattie Ashmore and Robert Ariail,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-371
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Larry G. Cantrell, of Pelzer, for Appellant.
R. Davis Howser, Andrew E. Haselden, Michael Todd Loftis and Sylvia P. Harrison, all of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Larry Cantrell brought this action against Beattie Ashmore and Robert Ariail, seeking to recover property forfeited after his arrest and to reinstate the forfeiture action to the jury trial docket.Â  The trial court dismissed the action.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS[2]
Cantrell was convicted of trafficking in cocaine in 1999.Â  Ashmore represented him at the time, and Ariail prosecuted the case on behalf of the State. Subsequent to the conviction, Ariail filed a complaint for forfeiture of items seized from Cantrell.Â Â Â  
At the time of the forfeiture action, Cantrell granted his mother a general power of attorney. Ashmore and Ariail reached a settlement regarding the forfeiture of certain items, with other items being placed in the possession of Cantrellâ€™s mother.Â  Cantrellâ€™s mother signed the consent agreement on his behalf.Â  The consent order was issued in March 2000. 
Cantrell filed a complaint in January 2003, in which he alleged:Â  â€œThe Defendants by deceit, trickery, and knowingly making a false statement of material fact and assisting Plaintiffâ€™s General Power of Attorney to commit fraud upon the Court.â€Â  He alleged he intended to assert his right to a jury trial in the forfeiture action and in no way consented or agreed to the compromise settlement. Cantrell also maintained his mother was led to believe he consented to the forfeiture and she â€œwould have never entered into this compromise settlement if she had known the truth that neither Defendants had discussed this matter with her son.â€Â  
For relief, Cantrell asked the court to â€œgrant his Motion to Restore his Forfeiture case No 99-CP-39-491 back on the docket for a jury trial.â€Â  Additionally, he sought an order requiring â€œthe Defendants to pay the Plaintiffs for all the property and return all the money contained within the Complaint for Forfeiture.â€Â  Finally, he sought payment of his costs and any other relief the court deemed just and proper.Â  
Ashmore and Ariail moved to dismiss the action pursuant to Rules 12(b)(6) and 12(c), SCRCP, on the ground that time for filing under the statute of limitations contained in section 15-3-550 of the South Carolina Code (2005) had passed.Â  Additionally, each filed an answer asserting numerous defenses including the complaint failed to state a claim upon which relief may be granted.Â  
The trial court issued a Form 4 order, which simply read:Â  â€œSolicitor Robert Ariail is DISMISSED.Â  Beattie Ashmore is DISMISSED.â€ (R.45). Cantrell failed to file a motion to reconsider pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Cantrell maintains the trial court erred in dismissing his action.Â  He alleges it was not barred by the two-year statute of limitations under section 15-3-550 of the South Carolina Code (2005) because he brought an action for fraud and not an action based upon the forfeiture, or in the alternative, the two-year statute of limitations was tolled.Â  We find Cantrellâ€™s arguments are not preserved as they were never ruled on by the trial court in its order, and he failed to raise them in a motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J.,Â  and BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The majority of the facts are derived from the complaint filed by Cantrell.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(1), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ann M. Kneece, individually and As Personal Representative of Robert E.
Kneece, deceased,        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William H. Babcock, M.D., and South Carolina Oncology Associates, P.A.,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-372
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kenneth M. Suggs, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Charles E. Hill and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Columbia, and John Hamilton Smith and William L. Howard, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this medical malpractice action, Ann M. Kneece, individually and as personal representative of Robert E. Kneece (collectively â€œKneeceâ€), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of William H. Babcock, M.D., and South Carolina Oncology Associates, P.A.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In early 1999, Robert Kneece was diagnosed with colon cancer.Â  Surgery was performed in February 1999, and the tumor and part of his colon were removed.Â  After the surgery, Mr. Kneece was referred to Dr. Babcock, an oncologist employed by South Carolina Oncology Associates, P.A., for follow-up care.Â  
At a visit on April 19, 1999, Dr. Babcock ordered blood tests to monitor Mr. Kneeceâ€™s carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level, which is considered a marker for cancer.Â  The initial CEA registered a count of 4.4, which was within the â€œnormalâ€ range though slightly higher than Mr. Kneeceâ€™s preoperative level of 3.8. A second CEA test in July revealed a level at 5.7, a number just slightly outside the normal range.Â  A third test was taken in January of 2000 which showed Mr. Kneeceâ€™s CEA level had become significantly elevated, with a CEA count of 28.5.Â  Dr. Babcock had the test repeated in February.Â  The resulting count was further elevated at 38.7.Â  A CT scan revealed several areas in the liver that were suspicious for metastatic disease.Â  A biopsy of the liver was positive for carcinoma.Â  Following the diagnosis, Mr. Kneece explored multiple courses of therapy.Â  Unfortunately, the treatments were unsuccessful and Mr. Kneece died from liver cancer on November 23, 2000, less than two years after the initial diagnosis.Â  
Kneece alleged Dr. Babcock negligently failed to make a timely diagnosis and that Dr. Babcock failed to initiate treatment in a timely fashion.Â  Specifically, Kneece argued Dr. Babcock took no action with regard to the elevated CEA in July 1999 and, as a result, was negligent in treating Mr. Kneece, which shortened his life.Â  
Prior to trial, both Kneece and Dr. Babcock deposed medical experts as to the standard of care, whether Dr. Babcock deviated from that standard, and whether Dr. Babcockâ€™s actions most probably caused the injury to Mr. Kneece.Â  As a result of these depositions, Dr. Babcock moved the circuit court for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court granted the summary judgment in favor of Dr. Babcock finding, as a matter of law that Kneece was unable to establish a causal connection between the delay in diagnosis and Mr. Kneeceâ€™s subsequent death.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Laurens Emergency Med. Specialists, P.A. v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 355 S.C. 104, 109, 584 S.E.2d 375, 377 (2003).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, the evidence and all the inferences which can be drawn therefrom should be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  At the summary judgment stage of litigation, the court does not weigh conflicting evidence with respect to a disputed material fact.Â  South Carolina Prop. & Cas. Guar. Assâ€™n v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 518, 548 S.E.2d 880, 883 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Kneeceâ€™s â€œshortened lifeâ€ argument
Kneece first argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Dr. Babcock because the circuit court failed to consider that Dr. Babcock â€œnegligently shortened Mr. Kneeceâ€™s lifeâ€ by failing to begin cancer treatments earlier.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for appeal.
In order to preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Holy Loch Distrib., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000).Â  Where a party raises an issue, but the circuit court never rules on it, the party must file a motion to alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate review.Â  Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991).
The circuit court order granting summary judgment did not address Kneeceâ€™s theory that Dr. Babcock could be held liable for shortening Mr. Kneeceâ€™s life.Â  Absent a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the order to receive a ruling on this issue from the circuit court, it is not preserved for our review.
II.Â  â€œLoss of chance of survivalâ€ doctrine
Kneece next alleges recovery in this matter should be allowed under the â€œloss of chance of survivalâ€ doctrine.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina Supreme Court expressly and unanimously rejected the â€œloss of chance of survivalâ€ doctrine in Jones v. Owings, 318 S.C. 72, 77, 456 S.E.2d 371, 374 (1995).Â  As Chief Justice Toal states in her treatise on South Carolina appellate practice, â€œthe Court of Appeals is an error-correction court, whereas the Supreme Court is a law-giving court.Â  The decisions of the Supreme Court bind the Court of Appeals.â€Â  Toal, Vafai & Muckenfuss, Appellate Practice in South Carolina, at 12 (2d ed. 2002).Â  See also S.C. Const., art. V. Â§ 9 (establishing the jurisdiction of the court of appeals and explaining the binding effect of supreme court opinions); Daniels v. City of Goose Creek, 314 S.C. 494, 498, 431 S.E.2d 256, 260 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding that any modification of supreme court case law must be undertaken by the supreme court).Â  
Therefore, we reject Kneeceâ€™s contention that the circuit court erred in denying recovery under the â€œloss of chance of survivalâ€ theory.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of William H. Babcock, M.D., and South Carolina Oncology Associates, P.A., is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
