THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
James A. Summersett, Jr.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-373
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed June 10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  James Summersett appeals his conviction for murder, arguing the trial court erred in three of its evidentiary rulings.Â  We are asked to decide: (1) whether certain testimony admitted was improper character evidence; (2) whether evidence of a prior bad act was properly admitted under Rule 404(b), SCRE; and (3) whether two rap songs admitted into evidence were sufficiently relevant and not unfairly prejudicial.Â  Finding no reversible error or abuse of discretion, we affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
This case concerns a fatal shooting that occurred during a street brawl involving Summersett and several other individuals on April 15, 2002.Â  During the fight, Summersett fired a pistol, killing Julian Grant.Â  Summersett claimed the shooting was an accident.Â  He was tried and convicted for murder.
The Fight and Shooting
The fight involved two families who lived on the same street and had known each other for many years.Â  It erupted in front of the home of Josephine Hawkins, the victimâ€™s grandmother.Â  Summersettâ€™s parents lived next door.
The fight initially started between Jason Grant (the victimâ€™s brother) and Travis Brown (Summersettâ€™s cousin) during an argument over an unpaid debt.Â  Their argument quickly escalated and turned physical.Â  Others soon joined in the fight, including Jeremy Hawkins (the victimâ€™s cousin) and Summersettâ€™s brother, Quincy.Â  Hawkins began striking Quincy in the head, prompting Summersett to join the fight.Â  Using the butt of his pistol, Summersett struck Hawkins in the head.Â  The victim, Julian Grant, then intervened.Â  According to trial testimony, Julian Grant was attempting to break up the fight, and in so doing, pushed Summersett, causing him to fall to the ground.Â  At that point, Summersettâ€™s gun fired,Â  fatally wounding Grant. 
Summersett then fled the area.Â  Law enforcement was called to the scene and immediately launched a search for Summersett.Â Â  A few hours after the shooting, Summersett telephoned William Thrower, an attorney who had represented Summersett in the past.Â  Thrower testified that Summersett explained he had shot Julian Grant by mistake.Â  Summersett also told Thrower he would not turn himself in until he could obtain a statement from eyewitnesses that could corroborate his version of events. 
Law enforcement continued its investigation and search for Summersett, but he managed to avoid detection in the days following the shooting.Â  Approximately two weeks later, Summersett was found living in a North Charleston motel where he was arrested and charged with the murder of Julian Grant.Â  
At Trial
Summersett testified at trial, denying he intentionally shot Grant.Â  On the stand, he admitted firing the weapon, but he maintained it was purely unintentional, discharging accidentally after he was pushed and fell to the ground.Â Â  Â Â  
The State presented two factual theories for its murder case against Summersett.Â  The first theory was simply that Summersett directly intended to shoot Grant.Â  In support of this theory, the State called several witnesses who testified that Summersett deliberately pointed and aimed the gun at Grant and shot.Â  The defense attempted to counter this theory by offering the testimony of eyewitnesses who claimed the gun fired accidentally when Summersett fell and hit the ground.Â  Summersett also took the stand and claimed the shooting was purely accidental.Â  The State attempted to rebut Summersettâ€™s claim of accident or mistake by offering the testimony of William Thrower regarding a 1993 incident in which Summersett shot a â€œfriendâ€ in the foot and claimed accident.Â  Defense counsel objected to this evidence under Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  The objection was overruled, and the testimony was admitted under the â€œabsence of mistake or accidentâ€ exception to Rule 404(b). 
The second factual theory offered by the State was that Summersett actually intended to shoot another person involved in the brawlâ€”Jeremy Hawkinsâ€”not Grant.Â  In support of this alternate theory, the State sought the admission of two rap songs written by Summersett and recorded at his music studio that contain lyrics expressing venomous threats directed at Hawkins.Â  In conjunction with these songs, the State offered evidence that Hawkins had been involved in a sexual relationship with Summersettâ€™s girlfriend and also that Hawkins had been providing information to the federal government in its investigation of illegal narcotics activity in the area.Â  Appellant objected to the admission of the rap songs, which the trial court overruled. 
At the conclusion of the trial, the jury found Summersett guilty on all charges, and the trial court sentenced Summersett to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.[1]
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Â 
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  â€œOn review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThis Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€ Id.Â  â€œThe admission and exclusion of evidence is largely a matter of trial judge discretion and his rulings will not be overturned on appeal unless he manifestly abuses his discretion and the defendant suffered prejudice as a result.â€Â  State v. Thompson, 305 S.C. 496, 502, 409 S.E.2d 420, 424 (Ct. App. 1991).
DISCUSSION
On appeal, Summersett challenges three of the trial courtâ€™s evidentiary rulings.Â  We address these arguments individually below.
I.Â  Admission of Character Evidence
Summersett first argues the trial court erred in admitting improper character evidence in the form of testimony concerning the fact that Summersett
fathered six children by five different women out of wedlock.Â  We conclude that any error, if found, would be harmless in light of other evidence adduced at trial.
The State began its cross-examination of Summersett with the following colloquy:

SOLICITOR:Â  All right, Jimmy.Â  By way of background, letâ€™s get some clarity on some of these things.Â  You were talking about you have one child?
SUMMERSETT:  No.
SOLICITOR:Â  You actually have five children; donâ€™t you?
SUMMERSETT:  Six.
SOLICITOR:Â  Six children?
SUMMERSETT: Yes.
SOLICITOR:Â  By how many different women?
SUMMERSETT:  Five.
. . . .
SOLICITOR:Â  Okay.Â  Have you ever had any of those children while you were in wedlock with your wife?Â  Did you ever have any children out of wedlock?
SUMMERSETT:  Iâ€™m not legally married.

Defense counsel then objected that the State was attempting to introduce improper character evidenceâ€”specifically arguing that the State was using this line of questioning to imply that â€œif you have one child out of wedlock you are a bad person.â€Â  The trial court overruled the objection and allowed the Stateâ€™s cross-examination on this subject to continue.
Initially, we note this argument may not be properly preserved for our review.Â  Defense counselâ€™s objection to the solicitorâ€™s cross-examination regarding Summersett having fathered multiple children out of wedlock came only after several questions on this subject had been asked and answered by Summersett. See State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 869, 873 (1994) (holding that a contemporaneous objection is required to preserve an issue for appellate review); State v. Sullivan, 310 S.C. 311, 314, 426 S.E.2d 766, 768 (1993) (holding that â€œ[t]o preserve an issue for appellate review, an appellant must object at his first opportunityâ€).Â  Therefore, it is arguable whether Summersettâ€™s trial counsel effectively preserved the objection to this line of questioning.Â  
Even if properly preserved, however, we find Summersett is not entitled to relief on this issue.Â  Rule 404(a), SCRE, states the general rule that â€œ[e]vidence of a personâ€™s character or a trait of character is not admissible for the purpose of proving action in conformity therewith on a particular occasion . . . .â€Â  However, when the accused offers evidence of his good character regarding specific character traits relevant to the crime charged, the prosecution has the right to cross-examine him as to particular bad acts or conduct. State v. Nelson, 331 S.C. 1, 6, 501 S.E.2d 716, 718 (1998).Â  The State is restricted, however, to showing bad character only for the traits initially focused on by the accused. State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 174, 508 S.E.2d 870, 878 (1998). 
The State argues the trial court properly admitted the evidence regarding Summersett having fathered six children by five different women out of wedlock because Summersett put this particular character trait in issue by virtue of several repeated references to his son, Ques, during his testimony on direct examination.Â  These references to his son occurred during Summersettâ€™s narrative of the events leading up to the April 15, 2002, shooting.Â  In describing his activities and movement that afternoon, Summersett mentioned that he picked up his son from school and took him to his baseball game and that taking care of his son in this fashion was part of his normal routine.Â  
In its argument to the trial judge and again in this appeal, the State asserts that the cumulative effect of this testimony was to paint a â€œbroad pictureâ€ that Summersett was a â€œdevoted fatherâ€ by â€œshowcasing only one son.â€Â  Accordingly, the State claims that Summersettâ€™s testimony regarding his son â€œopened the doorâ€ to impeachment of his â€œgood father image.â€ 
Based on our review of Summersettâ€™s testimony we find a close question is presented as to the admissibility of the testimony at issue.Â  While it is perhaps arguable that Summersett was attempting to leverage his testimony to foster a â€œgood father image,â€ it appears more likely that Summersett was simply referring to his son in a fashion purely incidental to his narrative description of the events prior to the shooting.Â  
Nevertheless, we find it unnecessary to reach an ultimate determination as to whether the trial judge abused his discretion in admitting this testimony because the error, if found, would be harmless in light of the other evidence of Summersettâ€™s promiscuity presented at trial.Â  Our supreme court has held that â€œwhere there is other properly admitted evidence of conduct demonstrating the particular character trait in question, there is no reversible error.â€ State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 196, 577 S.E.2d 445, 448 (2003); see also State v. Brown, 344 S.C. 70, 75, 543 S.E.2d 552, 555 (2001) (noting that â€œ[t]he erroneous admission of character evidence is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt if its impact is minimal in the context of the entire recordâ€); State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 463, 469 S.E.2d 49, 54 (1996) (instructing that error in admission of evidence is harmless where it is cumulative to other evidence which was properly admitted); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (noting that any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless).Â  
In this case, three witnesses took the stand before Summersett who each testified that Summersett had an ongoing sexual relationship with Jeremy Hawkinsâ€™ wife, Tasha Hawkins, while Summersett was either married or engaged to another woman.Â  Additionally, Jeremy Hawkins testified that he was having an affair with Summersettâ€™s fiancÃ©e, and that Summersett was aware of this fact at the time.Â  Summersett raised no objection to any of this testimony about his promiscuity.Â  Accordingly, we conclude that the Stateâ€™s cross-examination of Summersett regarding his having children out of wedlock by different women was merely cumulative to the other, unobjected-to evidence of Summersettâ€™s promiscuity and infidelity contained in the record.Â  Any error by the trial court in allowing the State to pursue this line of questioning was therefore harmless.
II.Â  Admission of Prior Bad Act Evidence
Summersett next asserts the trial court improperly admitted into evidence a prior bad act as relevant to the issue of whether Summersett accidentally or intentionally shot the victim in the present case.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.
At trial, the State sought to introduce evidence that Summersett had previously been charged with assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK) stemming from an incident in which he shot another person during an argument.Â  The trial court held a hearing outside the presence of the jury to determine the admissibility of this evidence.
During the hearing, the State presented the testimony of William Thrower, Summersettâ€™s former attorney.Â  Thrower testified that Summersett shot Ernie Riley in the foot during a confrontation between the two in 1993.Â  After the incident, Summersett fled the scene, but later called Riley to apologize for the shooting, claiming it was unintentional and purely accidental.Â  Summersett was later found, arrested, and charged with ABIK.Â  In his defense, Summersett claimed Riley was a friend and that he inadvertently shot Riley while aiming the pistol towards the ground.Â  Thrower testified that Summersett ultimately entered a plea of nolo contendere to the ABIK charge.Â  
The State argued that Throwerâ€™s testimony was admissible to show lack of mistake or accident by Summersett when he shot Grant in the present case.Â  Summersett objected to the evidence of the prior shooting, arguing the incident with Riley was not relevant because it was too remote, dissimilar, and unrelated to the present charge and that admission of this evidence would be highly inflammatory and unfairly prejudicial.Â  He also argued that the State had failed to offer clear and convincing proof of the underlying facts of the prior shooting.
The law in South Carolina regarding the admission of evidence of prior bad acts is well established.Â  As a general rule, evidence of other crimes or prior bad acts is inadmissible to show criminal propensity or to demonstrate the accused is a bad individual.Â  State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 143, 591 S.E.2d 646, 652 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Such evidence is admissible, however, when it tends to establish (1) motive, (2) intent, (3) the absence of mistake or accident, (4) a common scheme or plan, or (5) the identity of the person charged with the present crime. Rule 404(b), SCRE; State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  To be admissible under one of these permitted exceptions, a prior bad act must first be established by clear and convincing evidence. State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 135, 536 S.E.2d 679, 683 (2000). Next, the record must support a logical relevance between the prior bad act and the crime for which the defendant is accused. State v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 634, 541 S.E.2d 833, 836 (2001). Finally, even if relevant, the trial court must exclude the evidence if its probative value is outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice. Rule 403, SCRE; State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 512, 514 S.E.2d 578, 582 (1999). Of course, the decision to admit contested evidence is entrusted to the sound discretion of the trial judge. State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001). 
In the present case, the trial court admitted the evidence of the prior shooting under the absence of mistake or accident exception to Rule 404(b), SCRE, and Lyle.Â  However, it limited its ruling to admission of the underlying conduct, not admission of the resulting conviction.Â  Summersett now contends the admission of this evidence was an abuse of discretion.Â  We are unpersuaded.

A.Â  Â Â Â  Clear and Convincing Evidence

First, we find no reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s finding there was clear and convincing evidence of the prior shooting.Â  â€œWhen considering whether there is clear and convincing evidence of other bad acts, this court is bound by the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.â€ State v. Tutton, 354 S.C. 319, 325, 580 S.E.2d 186, 189 (Ct. App. 2003); see also State v. Wallace, 364 S.C. 130, 611 S.E.2d 332, 335 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting that â€œ[t]his court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidenceâ€). In this case, there is evidence in the record in the form of William Throwerâ€™s detailed testimony concerning his direct knowledge of the prior shooting and Summersettâ€™s subsequent claim of accident.Â  The determination as to whether this testimony clearly and convincingly established that the prior shooting occurred is a matter well within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Tutton, 354 S.C. at 325-26, 580 S.E.2d at 190.Â  We find no abuse of that discretion in light of Throwerâ€™s proffered testimony.

B.      Relevance Under the Absence of Mistake
or Accident Exception to LyleÂ Â Â Â Â  

Having found the record supports the trial courtâ€™s ruling that Summersett committed the prior bad act, we must next determine whether there is a logical relevance between the prior act and the crime charged.Â  We find this necessary connection is sufficiently established.Â  
The determination of logical relevancy does not depend simply upon an enumeration of the similarities between the two incidents.Â  Rather, the evidence in question is relevant if it tends to prove or disprove a material fact or element of the crime charged. See State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 28, 393 S.E.2d 364, 369 (1990); State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 241, 609 S.E.2d 572, 582 (Ct. App. 2005). â€œ[I]fÂ  [the evidence of the other crime] is logically pertinent in that it reasonably tends to prove a material fact in issue, it is not to be rejected merely because it incidentally proves the defendant guilty of another crime.â€ Lyle, 125 S.C. at 416, 118 S.E. at 807.
The material fact at the very center of this case concerns whether Summersett intentionally or accidentally shot the victim.Â  The evidence of the prior shooting of Ernie Riley is directly probative on this critical question of fact.Â  Evidence in the record indicates that, in both incidents, Summersett engaged in a violent confrontationâ€”whether actual or threatenedâ€”with an acquaintance.Â  Both times Summersett wielded a firearm in a threatening manner.Â  Ernie Riley testified that, in the first incident, Summersett confronted him on the street, grabbed Rileyâ€™s gun, and threatened to shoot him.Â  During this altercation, Summersett fired the weapon, striking Riley in the foot.Â  Likewise, in the present case, Summersett entered a fight brandishing a weapon, hammer cocked, and even used the firearm as a blunt-force object to strike another person in the head.Â  As in the Riley incident, Summersett fired the weapon during the brawl, wounding another personâ€”this time fatally.Â  In both cases, Summersett fled the scene and later claimed accident.
These closely parallel facts tend to prove Summersett acted with full knowledge of the risks that obtain when brandishing and using a firearmÂ  when engaged in actual or threatened physical violence against another person.Â  Such knowledge makes it substantially less likely Summersett haplessly and unintentionally fired his weapon in the present case as he claims to have done.Â  The logical relevancy between the two incidents is therefore clear and unmistakable. 
We acknowledge that evidence of this prior shooting potentially paints Summersett as an individual prone to deadly violence.Â  This fact is not to be lightly dismissed.Â  Nevertheless, when, as in the instant case, the logical relevance between two incidents is clearly perceived, we may notâ€”consistent with the mandate of Lyleâ€”choose to ignore the evidence of the prior act simply because it incidentally proves the defendant is guilty of another crime.

C.Â Â Â Â Â  Balancing Probative Value and
Prejudice               

Finally, even if the evidence is clear and convincing and logically relevant within a Lyle exception, the trial court must exclude it under Rule 403, SCRE, if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant. See State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 468, 523 S.E.2d 787, 791 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Rule 403, SCRE).Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the Rule 403 balancing weighed in favor of admitting the evidence.Â  
In this case, the Rule 403 calculus is in our view a close one.Â  We recognize that the violent nature of the prior act and its similarity to the crime charged enhanced the danger of unfair prejudice in this case.Â  However, it is exactly these close questions that give rise to the deferential abuse of discretion standard of review.Â  Inherent in this standard is the well-settled recognition that there are difficult evidentiary questions that turn on matters uniquely within the purview of the trial court.Â  
The trial court is uniquely positioned to make the careful, nuanced judgments required when balancing fact-specific concepts like probative value and prejudice, and we are reluctant to disturb the sound exercise of that discretion.[2]Â  See State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 378, 580 S.E.2d 785, 794 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting that the Court of Appeals should â€œreview a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding Rule 403 pursuant to the abuse of discretion standard and are obligated to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgmentâ€); State v. Grace, 350 S.C. 19, 28, 564 S.E.2d 331, 335 (Ct. App. 2002) (stating that â€œ[a] trial courtâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value versus prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in exceptional circumstancesâ€); State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 358, 543 S.E.2d 586, 593 (Ct. App. 2001) (opining that â€œ[a] trial judgeâ€™s balancing decision under Rule 403 should not be reversed simply because an appellate court believes it would have decided the matter otherwise because of a differing view of the highly subjective factors of the probative value or the prejudice presented by the evidenceâ€), overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005). 
Because the balancing of probative value and the danger of unfair prejudice presented such a close question in this case, we find the issue fell squarely within the ambit of the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion, and we are unpersuaded of the need to overturn the trial courtâ€™s decision.
III.Â  Admission of Rap Songs
Summersettâ€™s final argument on appeal is that the trial court abused its discretion in admitting two rap songs and related testimony into evidence.Â  We disagree.
The State sought to introduce the rap songs into evidence in order to prove Jeremy Hawkins was Summersettâ€™s intended target when he fired his handgun during the street brawl in April 2002.Â  Summersett admitted he participated in writing and producing both songs at his record studio and admitted the lyrics directly refer to Jeremy Hawkins (specifically mentioned in the song by his nickname, â€œScroogeâ€).Â  Importantly, Summersett does not deny the clear animus towards Hawkins conveyed throughout the lyrics to these songs.Â  For example, Summersett explained that passages in the songs such as, â€œNow tell me how does it feel to be the snitch on the block / You sold your soul to the devil cuzâ€™ you have no heart,â€ refer specifically to the fact that it was widely believed in the community that Hawkins was acting as a confidential informant for federal authorities in an ongoing narcotics investigation.Â  Along this same line, a subsequent passage reads, â€œSo you best check yourself, bulletproof yourself, and tell them feds they best help you protect yourself.â€Â  
Other parts of the songs allude to Hawkinsâ€™ adulterous affairs with Summersettâ€™s girlfriend and Summersettâ€™s own affair with Hawkinsâ€™ wife: â€œNow let me tell you something thatâ€™s true / When I was locked up, you f---ed my bitch and now Iâ€™m f---ing yours too.â€Â  Again, Summersett admitted these lyrics refer specifically to Hawkins.
Defense counsel objected to the admission of these songs, arguing they were highly inflammatory because of the profanity and violence depicted and were not sufficiently probative of any intent by Summersett to harm Hawkins because the lyrics were too general or vague and were written at a time too remote from the shooting.Â  The trial court overruled the objection and admitted the evidence with the following instruction to the jury:

If you should decide that the lyrics are generalized music lyrics, you must not consider them in any way because generalized lyrics including any generalized threats of violence found in a musical composition are not relevant in any way.
On the other hand, should you decide the lyrics are specific as to Jeremy Hawkins, you may give those lyrics such weight, if any, as you deem appropriate only as to issues of motive and intent about which issues I will fully explain in the law in my concluding instructions to you.
You must not consider these lyrics as evidence of the defendantâ€™s character or in any other way inconsistent with my specific instructions.Â  

The trial court did, however, grant defense counselâ€™s request that a transcript of the lyrics not be admitted into evidence.Â  Instead, the two rap songs at issue were played in their entirety to the jury from a compact disc recording.Â  
We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the songs into evidence.Â  Our supreme court addressed a similar question concerning the admissibility of music lyrics in State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 552 S.E.2d 300 (2001).Â  In that case, the trial court admitted into evidence rap lyrics the accused had written in jail while awaiting trial for the underlying murder charge.Â  The lyrics at issue in Cheeseboro contained violent references to â€œleaving no prints and bodies left in a pool of blood.â€ Id. at 550, 552 S.E.2d at 313.Â Â  Applying the basic threshold relevancy analysis set out in Rule 403, SCRE, the supreme court found the admission of this evidence was error because the lyrics lacked any connection to the crimes committed:Â  â€œWe find these references too vague in context to support the admission of this evidence. . . . [T]hese lyrics contain only general references glorifying violence.â€ Id.Â  The court therefore concluded that â€œ[t]he minimal probative value of this document is far outweighed by its unfair prejudicial impact as evidence of appellantâ€™s bad character, i.e. his propensity for violence in general.â€Â  Id.
Applying the same Rule 403, SCRE, relevancy analysis in the present case compels a different conclusion.Â  Unlike the vague lyrics at issue in Cheeseboro, the songs admitted in the present caseâ€”by Summersettâ€™s own admissionâ€”refer specifically to Jeremy Hawkins.Â  Instead of â€œgeneral references glorifying violence,â€ the songs in this case convey clear animus in the form of violent and vitriolic lyrics directed at Hawkins.Â  The message of these songs is therefore clearly probative of Summersettâ€™s alleged motive and intent to kill Hawkins.Â  While we recognize the possibility that the jury could improperly consider the overall violence and profanity of these songs as reflecting poorly upon Summersettâ€™s character and his propensity for violence in general, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s determination that the danger of unfair prejudice is outweighed by the probative value that arises from the pointed animus conveyed in these songs Summersett wrote and produced.Â  Moreover, the danger of unfair prejudice was diminished by the trial courtâ€™s instruction to the jury as to the limited purposes for which they could consider this evidence.Â  Notably, Summersett raised no objection to the adequacy of this instruction.
For these reasons, we conclude the trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the two raps songs into evidence.
CONCLUSION
In sum, though we find this case presents a number of difficult evidentiary questions, we conclude the trial courtâ€™s rulings did not exceed the prescribed legal and discretionary bounds discussed above or otherwise rise to the level of reversible error.Â  Finding none of Summersettâ€™s claims on appeal warrant reversal, we affirm his conviction in all respects.
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] In addition to the murder charge, Summersett was also charged with possession of a firearm during the commission of a crime of violence.Â  In light of the sentence imposed for the murder conviction, the trial court found it unnecessary to pronounce sentence for the conviction for possession of a firearm during the commission of a crime of violence. 
[2] Viewing the record as a whole, it is notable that the Riley incident was only one of several similar prior bad acts the State attempted to admit into evidence.Â  Carefully applying the Lyle analysis, the trial court thoroughly examined each of these prior acts to determine admissibilityâ€”ultimately finding the Riley incident alone satisfied the standard for admission.

text:

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Dymaris McFarlin, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Charles M. McFarlin, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Tommy B. Edwards, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-378
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        William Patrick Yon, of Anderson, for Appellant.
        William N. Epps, Jr., of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action, Charles McFarlin (Husband) appeals a family court order holding him in contempt for violations of an earlier temporary order.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS

On April 2, 2003, Dymaris McFarlin (Wife) filed a complaint for divorce and a motion for temporary relief against Husband.Â  After a hearing on her request for temporary relief, the family court issued a temporary order awarding Wife possession of the marital home and ordering Husband to bring the mortgage current as of May 1, 2003, with Wife bearing responsibility for the mortgage thereafter.Â  The family court further ordered Husband to pay $2,000 per month in alimony beginning May 1, 2003, with the express qualification that the court could grant Husband reimbursement of this alimony upon a hearing on the merits of the underlying divorce action.Â  
On June 3, 2003, Wife filed a rule to show cause against Husband, alleging he failed to comply with the temporary order.Â  Wife asserted Husband failed to bring the mortgage current as of May 1, 2003, causing the mortgage holder to foreclose, and that he refused to make alimony payments.Â  Husband denied Wifeâ€™s allegations, arguing he did not willfully violate the temporary order, but was unable to make the payments due to disability and an erroneous calculation of his income.Â  Husband also alleged that Wife committed fraud on the court by falsifying e-mails to support an untruthful adultery allegation. 
After a hearing on July 30, 2003, the family court found Husband was capable of making the mortgage payments through May 1 and held him in willful contempt.Â  Husband was sentenced to six months in jail, suspended upon payment of the mortgage up to the specified date within 45 days of the contempt order. Â Â 
Based upon Husbandâ€™s reported earnings from April 2003 through the end of July, the family court also found Husband in willful contempt of the temporary alimony order and sentenced him to six months in jail, suspended upon payment of half the $6,000 arrearage.Â  Due to Husbandâ€™s documented minor knee surgery, the family court held the remainder of the arrearage in abeyance until the final hearing and ordered that Husband pay only $850 per month from August 1 until October 31, 2003.Â  Husbandâ€™s motion to reconsider was denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999). A finding of contempt, however, should not be reversed on appeal unless it is without evidentiary support or amounts to an abuse of discretion. Stone v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 840, 840 (1988).
  LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court erred in finding him in contempt because the evidence presented at the hearing did not support a finding that he willfully violated the temporary order.Â  We disagree.[2]
Section 20-7-1350 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) states that an â€œadult who willfully violates, neglects, or refuses to obey or perform a lawful order of the court . . . may be proceeded against for contempt of court.â€Â  For the purposes of determining contempt, â€œ[a]n act is willful if â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€Â  Wilson v. Walker, 340 S.C. 531, 538, 532 S.E.2d 19, 22 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)).Â  The moving party must show the existence of a court order and facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.Â  Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 338, 491 S.E.2d 583, 588 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Thereafter,Â  â€œthe burden shifts to the respondent to establish his defense and inability to comply.â€Â  Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989).Â  The record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct before a party may be held in contempt.Â  Id.
In the present case, the temporary order clearly mandates that Husband bring the mortgage current as of May 1, 2003 and pay Wife $2000 per month in alimony.Â  Husband did not deny his failure to comply with the order, but asserted the violations were not willful because of his financial situation. A review of the record reveals substantial evidence supporting the family courtâ€™s finding of willful contempt.Â  Husband testified that he earned $15,983 from April 21 to July 21, 2003, the time period in question.Â  Although Husband had sufficient income to comply with the family courtâ€™s order, he chose to use his income for other purposes.Â  Husband was clearly capable of paying for goods and services such as utilities, groceries, a private detective, and his attorney, but did not attempt to pay any portion of the money he owed to Wife.Â  Based upon these facts, we find the record clearly and specifically reflects Husbandâ€™s contemptuous behavior, and Husband did not meet his burden in proving he was unable to comply.
Husband also contends that Wifeâ€™s unilateral listing of the marital home for sale at an inflated price has negatively affected his ability to comply with the temporary order.Â  This issue, however, was satisfactorily resolved by the family courtâ€™s contempt order.Â  Paragraph 10 of the family courtâ€™s order states the following:
As to the sale of the marital home, I find that [Husband] shall have full rights to meet with the listing realtor for a discussion of sales price.Â  If the parties cannot agree on the fair market price to be asked for the home, either party may make a Motion to submit that issue to the Court for determination.
As to the affect of Wifeâ€™s alleged unilateral insistence on asking an unreasonably high price for the home on Husbandâ€™s past ability to comply with the temporary order, the family court found Husband was able to comply notwithstanding Wifeâ€™s behavior.Â  As discussed above, the evidence supported this finding. 
For the foregoing reasons, the family courtâ€™s contempt order is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Husband also makes several arguments relating to the merits of Wifeâ€™s allegations of adultery as a ground for divorce.Â  These issues are not presently ripe for our review.Â  The purpose of a temporary order is to maintain the status quo until the issues of a case can be determined in a family court hearing on their merits.Â  The present order expressly reserves the family courtâ€™s power to reimburse Husband all payments made pursuant to the temporary order following a hearing on the validity of Wifeâ€™s allegations.Â  Because these issues have yet to be resolved in their proper forum, a divorce hearing in the family court, we do not address them here.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and AssistantÂ  Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, allÂ  of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Â Nathan D. Smith appeals a guilty plea to one count each of armed robbery and safecracking.Â  The trial court sentenced him to concurrent sentences of ten years on each charge.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On August 4, 2002, Nathan Smith, Jeremiah Washington, and Ishmael Wilson entered a local gas station armed and wearing masks.Â  Upon entering, Washington forced one of the employees at gunpoint to open the cash register and demanded that she lay on the floor while he emptied its contents. Â 
While Washington was so occupied, Wilson and Smith went to the rear of the store.Â  There they held another employee at gunpoint and used her to get into the office where they encountered a third employee who was counting the nightâ€™s receipts.Â  They took what money they could find and then forced an employee at gunpoint to open the storeâ€™s safe.Â  After taking all the paper money from the safe, Wilson and Smith ran back to the front of the store where they met up with Washington before fleeing the scene.Â  
During the course of the robbery, the employees were able to identify Washington and Wilson.Â  Wilson was identified as a former employee of the store and thus, the authorities were able to obtain his address from employee files.Â  When officers arrived at Wilsonâ€™s home a short time later, all three perpetrators were arrested.Â  A subsequent search of the home produced over $25,000 in cash and a .45 caliber pistol.Â Â  
Smith, Washington, and Wilson were charged with two counts of armed robbery, safecracking, and conspiracy.Â  On October 23, 2003, Smith and Washington appeared before the circuit court to enter guilty pleas.Â  In exchange for pleading guilty to one count of armed robbery and safecracking, the State agreed to dismiss the remaining armed robbery and conspiracy charges.Â  In addition, due to a lack of prior criminal history, the State recommended minimum sentences.Â  
 After ensuring the defendants understood their constitutional rights and that their pleas were voluntarily and intelligently given, the trial court, without objection from either defendant, accepted the Stateâ€™s recommendation and gave both the minimum possible sentencesâ€”concurrent terms of ten years on each charge.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Smith argues the trial court erred in accepting his plea to safecracking because the facts of the robbery do not satisfy of the elements of the charge.Â  We disagree.
It is axiomatic, that to preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  See State v. Powers, 331 S.C. 37, 501 S.E.2d 116 (1998) (holding failure to raise constitutional issue at trial precluded its consideration on appeal).Â  As mentioned previously, neither Smith nor his cohort raised any objections to the trial court during the plea proceeding.Â  Furthermore, â€œ[t]he general rule is that guilty pleas, freely and voluntarily entered, act as a waiver of all non-jurisdictional defects and defenses, including the claims of a violation of a constitutional right prior to the plea.â€Â  Whetsell v. State, 276 S.C. 295, 297, 277 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1981).
Because Smith does not claim the trial court lacked jurisdiction, his argument would be more properly raised in an action for post-conviction relief.Â  See e.g., Fossick v. State, 317 S.C. 375, 453 S.E.2d 899 (1995).Â  
AFFIRMED. [1]
ANDERSON, STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott Assistant Attorney General Adrianne L. Turner, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Randy Johnson appeals the dismissal of his petition for a writ of habeas corpus.Â  Johnson argues his petition for a writ of habeas corpus should be treated as an application for post-conviction relief so that he can pursue an appeal of his first PCR action under Austin v. State, 305 S.C. 453, 409 S.E.2d 395 (1991). We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities: Aice v. State, 305 S.C. 448, 409 S.E.2d 392 (1991) (holding successive applications are disfavored and the burden is on the applicant to establish that any new ground raised in a subsequent application could not have been raised in a previous application); State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 587 S.E.2d 691 (2003) (holding in order to preserve an issue for appellate review it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge).
AFFIRMED. [2]

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        John Ingle, d/b/a Ingle & Company, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Ken Kuszmaul, Environmental Specialties, Inc., Indiana Lumbermen’s Mutual Insurance Co., Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District, Spartanburg Water System and Spartanburg Metropolitan District, Defendants, 
        of whom Ken Kuszmaul and Environmental Specialties, Inc., are, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-393
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 15, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Adam Fisher, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellants.Â  
        Charles Preston Edwards, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John Ingle sued Environmental Specialties, Inc. (ESI) and Ken Kuszmaul alleging breach of contract.Â  After a bench trial, the trial court awarded Ingle $56,471 on the contract and $16,805.76 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  ESI and Kuszmaul appeal.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.[1]
FACTS
ESI contracted to build a project for Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District.Â  This contract required ESI to obtain a payment bond.Â  ESI obtained the bond from Indiana Lumbermenâ€™s Mutual Insurance Co.Â  
Kuszmaul, on behalf of ESI, contacted John Ingle about performing subcontract work on the project.Â  Ingle and ESI entered into an oral agreement under which Ingle agreed to construct a pre-engineered building, including laying the foundation and installing yard pipe to the building.Â  
ESI, Kuszmaul, and Ingle later disagreed on the amount ESI contracted to pay Ingle for his work.Â  Ingle filed a mechanicâ€™s lien on the sewer districtâ€™s property seeking payment of $56,471 plus costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Ingle then filed a complaint and lis pendens seeking to foreclose on the mechanicâ€™s lien or, in the alternative, seeking payment pursuant to the payment bond.Â  The trial court issued a consent order pursuant to the partiesâ€™ agreement to dismiss the mechanicâ€™s lien and lis pendens, in exchange for the sewer districtâ€™s deposit of approximately $75,000 into escrow pending resolution of the partiesâ€™ dispute.Â  
Ingle filed an amended complaint against Kuszmaul, ESI, and Lumbermenâ€™s alleging ESI owed him $56,471 for work performed.Â  Ingle also sought incidental and consequential damages and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
ESI, Kuszmaul, and Lumbermenâ€™s answered Ingleâ€™s complaint, denying all material allegations and asserting counterclaims including:Â  (1) breach of contract; (2) breach of warranty; (3) negligence; and (4) quantum meruit.Â  Kuszmaul and ESI claimed Ingleâ€™s work contained numerous defects, and was not performed in a timely manner.Â  Kuszmaul and ESI alleged they suffered actual, consequential, and special damages because Ingleâ€™s performance damaged their relationship with the sewer district.Â  In addition, Kuszmaul and ESI claimed damages as a result of performing or hiring other subcontractors to perform work Ingle did not complete.Â  Kuszmaul and ESI also alleged that due to the absence of a statutory or contractual provision permitting the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, Ingle was not entitled to fees.Â  
The trial court found the parties entered into a contract entitling Ingle to receive $72,000 for his services.Â  The court thus awarded Ingle $56,471, the unpaid balance due under the contract,[2] and $16,805.76 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  In addition, the trial court found for Ingle on all counterclaims and set-offs.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for breach of contract is an action at law.Â  Sherman v. W & B Enters., Inc., 357 S.C. 243, 247, 592 S.E.2d 307, 309 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, our jurisdiction extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Kemp v. Rawlings, 358 S.C. 28, 34, 594 S.E.2d 845, 848 (2004).Â  Therefore, we will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they are wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  Id. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Breach of Contract 
ESI and Kuszmaul (hereinafter referred to collectively as ESI) argue the trial court erred in finding Ingle did not breach the contract and in finding ESI breached the contract.Â  ESI asserts the parties agreed to a contract price of $47,000, rather than $72,000, and ESI did not breach the contract by failing to pay Ingle the additional $56,471.Â  In addition, ESI claims Ingle failed to perform under the terms of the contract.Â  We disagree.
We find evidence existed to support the trial courtâ€™s findings of a contract price of $72,000 and ESIâ€™s breach of the contract.Â  The amount due under a contract is for the fact finder.Â  J.J. Lawter Plumbing v. Wen Chow Intâ€™l Trade & Inv., Inc., 286 S.C. 49, 55, 331 S.E.2d 789, 792 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  The failure to make payment as provided in a contract constitutes a substantial breach of the contract.Â  Zemp Constr. Co. v. Harmon Bros. Constr. Co., 225 S.C. 361, 366, 82 S.E.2d 531, 533 (1954).Â  
Ingle testified he sent a fax outlining the work he proposed to do on the project.Â  Ingle stated that after he sent the fax, he and Kuszmaul had a conversation concerning the cost of Ingleâ€™s work.Â  Ingle maintained he quoted Kuszmaul a price of $72,000 for the work and Kuszmaul agreed to the price.Â  Kuszmaul admitted he did not pay at least two of the invoices he received from Ingle.Â  There is evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s findings of the contract price and ESIâ€™s breach of contract. 
In addition, we find evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s finding that Ingle did not breach the contract.Â  ESI asserts Ingle breached the contract by failing to complete the work he contracted to perform.Â  One who prevents a condition of a contract cannot rely on the other partyâ€™s resulting nonperformance in an action for breach of contract.Â  Champion v. Whaley, 280 S.C. 116, 120, 311 S.E.2d 404, 406 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Ingle admitted he did not install a base plate in the bottom of the sledge tank and the chlorine chamber, as the parties agreed.Â  However, Ingle asserted he could not perform this task because, although he had repeatedly requested the tank be dewatered, he was never able to enter the chlorine contact chamber due to water in the tank.Â  Ingle testified this task would have taken about two hours.Â  Other than this item, Ingle contends ESI did not perform any other task on his behalf.Â  Thus, we find evidence existed to support the trial courtâ€™s determination that Ingle fulfilled his obligations under the agreement, and therefore did not breach that agreement.Â  
II.Â  Set-Off
ESI argues the trial court erred in denying its request to set off amounts owed to Ingle for labor and materials it supplied to complete Ingleâ€™s work and the cost of supplies provided to Ingle.Â  We find no error.
â€œIn a situation where a plaintiff supposedly owes a defendant monies, but nevertheless brings a suit in contract against the defendant, the proper defense to the action is a counterclaim or a set-off.â€Â  Carolina Mech. Contractors, Inc. v. Yeargin Constr. Co., 261 S.C. 1, 12, 198 S.E.2d 224, 230 (1973).Â  A party claiming a set-off has the burden of establishing the amount of the alleged set-off with reasonable certainty.Â  Diamond Swimming Pool Co. v. Broome, 252 S.C. 379, 386, 166 S.E.2d 308, 312 (1969).Â  
Ingle testified that ESI was not required to perform any work on behalf of Ingle except for the installation of the base plate in the chlorine chamber, which Ingle was prevented from completing.Â  In addition, Eric Ingle, Ingleâ€™s son who worked on the project, testified the work performed on the job site by ESI related to ESIâ€™s performance under its contract with the sewer district, and not work Ingle agreed to perform.Â  Thus, we find evidence in the record to support the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny ESIâ€™s claims for set-off.Â  
III.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
ESI argues the trial court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Ingle.Â  Specifically, ESI contends this award was not supported by a term of the contract or a statutory provision providing for attorneyâ€™s fees, and thus, the trial court abused its discretion in making the award.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œGenerally, attorney fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.â€Â  Seckinger v. The Vessel, Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 386, 483 S.E.2d 775, 777 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The trial court awarded attorneyâ€™s fees based on the mechanicâ€™s lien Ingle filed.Â  Section 29-5-20 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), governing mechanicâ€™s liens, allows the trial court, in its discretion, to award the prevailing party reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  However, the parties consented to dismiss the action to foreclose on Ingleâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien, and the trial court ordered dismissal.Â  Thus, we find no entitlement to attorneyâ€™s fees under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.
Ingle asserts even if attorneyâ€™s fees are not available under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, sections 29-5-440 and 11-1-120 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), providing a claimant the right to sue on a payment bond, entitle him to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.Â  These sections are part of the mechanicâ€™s lien statutory scheme and permit a direct action on the payment bond against the bonding company (section 29-5-440) and explain the procedure for such a suit (section 11-1-120).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-1-120 (Supp. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-440 (Supp. 2004).Â  â€œA statute allowing attorney fees is in derogation of the common law and must be strictly construed.â€Â  Belton v. State, 339 S.C. 71, 74, 529 S.E.2d 4, 5 (2000).Â  Sections 29-5-440 and 11-1-120 do not specifically provide for payment of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Therefore, based on our strict construction of these statutes, we decline to read such a provision into the language of the statute.Â  In addition, the payment bond itself does not provide for the payment of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, Ingle cannot recover attorneyâ€™s fees based on his action for payment under the payment bond.Â  
Finally, the parties do not allege their oral agreement authorized the award of attorneyâ€™s fees in the case of litigation pertaining to the contract.Â  Therefore, we find the trial court abused its discretion in awarding Ingle attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the trial courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART. 
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Inclusive of change order charges and previous partial payments.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Michael F. Dehoney, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        S.C. Department of Corrections, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-394
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 15, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Michael F. Dehoney, of Bennettsville, for Appellant.
        Kelli Gregg Maddox, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael F. Dehoney appeals a circuit court order denying his motion for costs in regard to a civil action he initiated against the South Carolina Department of Corrections (â€œSCDCâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1992, Dehoney was convicted of unlawful use of a vehicle and murder.Â  Dehoney has completed his sentence for unlawful use of a vehicle, but continues to serve a life sentence for murder. 
In October 2001, Dehoney initiated a civil action against SCDC pursuant to the South Carolina Tort Claims Act and 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.Â  Dehoney alleged SCDC wrongfully recorded in his prison records that he was involved in an escape or escape related event.Â  SCDC removed the action to federal court, but the case was remanded back to state court following a finding that the action was essentially a state law claim.Â  
At a July 2003 hearing on the matter, Dehoney acknowledged his prison records were currently accurate with respect to his â€œescape screen,â€ but asked the circuit court for an order preventing SCDC from changing it.Â  The Department asserted it had no reason to alter Dehoneyâ€™s escape report unless another escape attempt was made in the future or it later became aware of a past escape event.Â  The circuit court, with Dehoneyâ€™s full approval, ordered his escape report be maintained in the current state for all incidents occurring before July 10, 2003.
Dehoney later filed a motion for an award of costs on the basis that, as the prevailing party, he was entitled to recoup his filing and service fees in conjunction with this action.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, holding Dehoney failed to establish a rule of court or statute authorizing costs against the State.Â  Dehoney then filed a very disrespectful motion to reconsider this ruling, which was likewise denied by the circuit court.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I. Award of Costs
Appellant argues the circuit court erred in denying his motion for costs accrued in the underlying civil action because Rule 54(d), SCRCP, entitles him to such.Â  We disagree.
The applicable portion of Rule 54(d), SCRCP, reads as follows:

  [C]osts shall be allowed as of course to the prevailing party unless the Court otherwise directs, but costs against the State, its officers and agencies shall be imposed only to the extent permitted by law. (emphasis added)

The plain language of the rule grants the circuit court the authority to award costs to a party, but in no way requires the court to do so.Â  Even if an award of costs against the SCDC is permissible in the present case,[2] it remains within the discretion of the circuit court to deny such an award.
An appellant court may affirm an order upon any ground appearing in the record on appeal.Â  Rule 220(C), SCACR; see also Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000).Â  Because several of Appellantâ€™s causes of action were withdrawn and the circuit court ruling essentially amounts to nothing more than a court-ordered maintenance of the status quo, we conclude Appellant was not a true prevailing party as contemplated by Rule 54(d), SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the denial of Appellantâ€™s motion for award of costs.
II. Clarity of Circuit Courtâ€™s Initial Order
Appellant also argues the circuit courtâ€™s order of July 10, 2003, which ordered that SCDC maintain his escape record in its current state for all incidents occurring before the date of the order, is vague, ambiguous, and allows the SCDC to circumvent its intent.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.
As the circuit court announced its ruling, the following exchange took place between Appellant and the circuit court:

  The Court:Â  And so what I will do is I will issue an order that says as to - - as of this date, July the 10th of 2003, that the [SCDC] offender management system classification review escape/attempt list shall be maintained as to incidents occurring prior to 2003 . . .
  Appellant:Â  Right.
  The Court:Â  - - Prior to July 10, 2003 - -
  Appellant:Â  Exactly.
  The Court:Â  It shall be maintained as it is currently stated - -
  Appellant:Â  Exactly.Â  

The circuit courtâ€™s final order contains identical language to that requested by Appellant at the hearing.Â  Appellant made no objection to the agreed upon relief, nor did he file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend this aspect of the order.Â  â€œA contemporaneous objection is required to preserve an issue for appellate review.â€Â  Hawkins v. Pathology Assocs. of Greenville, P.A., 330 S.C. 92, 111, 498 S.E.2d 395, 406 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Accordingly, this issue is not properly before us.Â  Should the SCDC attempt in the future to circumvent the intent of the circuit courtâ€™s order, the proper venue for legal recourse is a rule to show cause in the circuit court, not appellate review of the initial order.
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] See Varn v. South Caorlina Depâ€™t of Highways and Pub. Transp., 311 S.C. 349, 354, 428 S.E.2d 895, 898 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œ[C]osts may be assessed against the State as well as any other Defendant.â€).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Autumn LaDawn Davis, f/k/a Autumn LaDawn Young, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Jimmy Bruce Young, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Orangeburg County
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-396
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 15, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Cynthia Bailey Berry, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
        Thomas E. Elliott, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jimmy Bruce Young appeals the family courtâ€™s order holding him in contempt of a restraining order.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Autumn LaDawn Davis and Young were divorced on May 27, 2003.Â Â Â  In the final divorce decree, the family court ordered: â€œeach of the parties shall be, and [] is hereby, enjoined and restrained from harassing, abusing, bothering, threatening, or interfering with the other party and from entering upon or attempting to enter upon the other partyâ€™s residence or place of employment.â€Â  
 In August of 2003, Davis filed a petition in support of the issuance of a rule to show cause requesting that the family court find Young in willful contempt for failure to pay alimony, failure to make automobile and insurance payments, and violation of the mutual restraining order.Â Â Â  Concerning the restraining order, Davis alleged Young had repeatedly driven to her home and walked about her property.Â  Â Â 
The family court issued a rule to show cause, and Young was served.Â  Young responded by, among other things, denying a violation of the restraining order. Â The contempt hearing was held on February 12, 2004.Â  Although Davis raised several issues in her original petition, the only issue adjudicated at the hearing was Youngâ€™s violation of the restraining order.Â  
At the hearing, Davis presented testimony and police incident reports in support of her claim that Young willfully violated the restraining order.Â  Davis testified that she had seen Young on numerous occasions at varying hours of the day, outside of her mobile home, at her back door, and parked in the mobile home park driveway, both alone and with others.Â  Specifically, Davis stated that Young showed up at her house on June 6, 2003, and tried to get in through the front door.Â  Davis also testified that, on June 9, 2003, Young pulled into her motherâ€™s front yard (next door to Davisâ€™s residence), pointed at Davis, made the shape of a gun with his hand, and then drove away.Â  On June 19, 2003, Young entered the mobile home park and kept watch on her from a car.Â  Another resident of the mobile home park, Emily Finley, corroborated Davisâ€™s testimony.Â  Finley testified she saw Young at the mobile home park on at least two occasions, and particularly remembered seeing Young and his brother sitting in a red truck watching Davisâ€™s mobile home.Â  Â Â 
By a bench order dated February 12, 2004, the family court held Young in willful contempt of the restraining order, sentenced him to three months in jail, suspended upon 30 days service, and ordered Young to pay Davis $1,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Young began serving his sentence immediately following the hearing.Â  On March 3, 2004, the family court issued a formal order in which Youngâ€™s contempt was characterized as â€œcivil.â€Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999). However, a finding of contempt should not be reversed on appeal unless it is without evidentiary support or amounts to an abuse of discretion. Stone v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 840, 840 (1988).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
In the final written order, the family court referred to Youngâ€™s contempt as â€œcivilâ€ in nature although the sanction, a definite period of incarceration, is indisputably indicative of criminal contempt.Â  No one argues on appeal that the contempt sentence was civil in nature.Â  Because the family courtâ€™s March 3, 2004, order erroneously characterizes the contempt as civil, Young argues this court should reverse the family court.Â  We disagree.
Contempt results from the willful disobedience of an order of the court, and before a court may hold a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically demonstrate the acts or conduct upon which such a finding is based.Â  Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 918 (1982).Â  A willful act is â€œone done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€Â  State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)).Â  Civil contempt must be proved by clear and convincing evidence. Poston v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106, 113, 502 S.E.2d 86, 89 (1998).Â  In a criminal contempt proceeding, the burden of proof is beyond a reasonable doubt. Id.Â  The determination of contempt ordinarily resides in the sound discretion of the trial judge. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. at 129, 447 S.E.2d at 217.
The determining factor in resolving whether contempt is civil or criminal is the purpose for which the power is exercised, including the nature of the relief and the purpose for which the sentence is imposed.Â  Poston, 331 S.C. at 111, 502 S.E.2d at 88.
Â  â€œThe purpose of civil contempt is â€˜to coerce the defendant to do the thing required by the order for the benefit of the complainant.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Gompers v. Buckâ€™s Stove & Range Co., 221 U.S. 418, 441 (1911)).Â  The sanctions for civil contempt are conditioned on compliance with the courtâ€™s order.Â  Poston, 331 S.C. at 112, 502 S.E.2d at 89.Â  The conditional nature of the punishment allows the contemnor to discharge himself of the sentence by â€œdoing what he had previously refused to do.â€Â  Id. (quoting Hicks v. Feiock, 485 U.S. 624, 633 (1988)).Â  
â€œThe primary purposes of criminal contempt are to preserve the courtâ€™s authority and to punish for disobedience of its orders.â€Â  Poston, 331 S.C. at 111, 502 S.E.2d at 88.Â  A penalty for criminal contempt is unconditional and punitive in nature.Â  Id.Â  The contemnor has no power to undo or remedy what has been done and cannot shorten the term by an affirmative act.Â  Id. at 111-12, 502 S.E.2d at 88-89.Â  
Here, the family courtâ€™s sanction was clearly criminal in nature.Â  Young was ordered to serve three months, suspended upon thirty days service, and had no ability to purge himself of the sentence.Â  The judgeâ€™s comments from the benchâ€”and resulting bench orderâ€”establish that the purpose of the contempt sentence was to punish Young for his violation of the restraining order.Â  The family court judge stated: 

  weighing all of the evidence that she [Davis] has presented, including that of her witness, I find that he was in violation of a court order on at least the occasion when the red truck was observed there by the eyewitness who testified . . . and I believe places him there in violation of the court order.Â  

That the subsequent order of March 3, 2004, contained language erroneously characterizing the contempt as civil in nature does not change the nature of the contempt itself, which was clearly punitive.[1]Â  
We are firmly convinced the family court judge applied the correct burden of proofâ€”beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  This is especially so when we consider the judgeâ€™s comments from the bench at the conclusion of the February 12, 2004, hearing.Â  Moreover, our review of the record indicates Davis presented sufficient evidence to support a finding Young was guiltyâ€”beyond a reasonable doubtâ€”of willfully violating the restraining order.Â  Davis testified that she had seen Young on numerous occasions outside of her mobile home, at her back door, and parked in the mobile home park driveway.Â  Her neighbor, Emily Finley, testified she saw Young, who she recognized from a previous meeting, at the mobile home park several times.Â  Finley distinctly recalled seeing Young and his brother sitting in a red truck watching Davisâ€™s mobile home.Â  The family court judge found this evidence credible, and we concur.Â  Although Young denied the general allegations, he admitted his brother owns a red truck.Â  Based on his observation of the witnesses, the family court judge found that the testimony of Davis and Finley was credible, whereas Youngâ€™s testimony that he did not violate the restraining order was not credible.Â  While we acknowledge the erroneous reference to the finding of civil contempt in the March 3, 2004, order, we find no basis for reversal, for Young was not legally prejudiced by this error.
CONCLUSION
Although the family court incorrectly characterized Youngâ€™s contempt as civil in the March 3, 2004, order, we find this mistake does not constitute reversible error.Â  The sanction for the contempt was criminal in nature, and ample evidence exists on the record to support a finding of criminal contempt.Â  Therefore, the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] As noted above, neither party to this appeal argues the contempt sentence was actually civil in nature.Â  Indeed, at the time the family court issued its March 3, 2004, written order, Young did not see the need to petition the family court for reconsideration or clarification of the discrepancy he now claims warrants a finding of reversible error.
